Memorandum:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Mission, British Columbia.

The Principal of the above mentioned school reports that the building is badly in need of painting as the stucco walls are beginning to crack, due to the lack of a protecting coating. The slate roof is also in poor condition. The Indian Commissioner agrees with the Principal and he has submitted quotations from Webster Brothers, Abbotsford, British Columbia and from M.A. Girard and Sons, New Westminster, British Columbia. The quotations of Webster Brothers for material and labour is $1065.00 and is much less than the quotation received from the other firm. The Indian Commissioner recommends the acceptance of the quotation received from Webster Brothers and I would appreciate it if the Minister would give his approval so that the work may be done in the near future.

This is a church-owned school and funds were provided in the current years' appropriation.

I enclose for your information the quotations mentioned above.

APPROVED

Encl:

AIR MAIL.

Ottawa, September 7, 1946.

Major D.M. MacKey, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, the Department approves the acceptance of the tender of Webster Brothers for painting, etc. at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School at a cost of $1005. for material and labour.

I presume that you will arrange for this work to be commenced immediately in order that it may be completed before winter.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Father Fleury, the Reverend Principal of Mission Residential School, has called on me advising that a 60-quart dough mixer (No. 6012), which probably cost $800, has been discarded by Shaughnessy Military Hospital and replaced by a new machine as it required some minor repairs reportedly amounting from $150 to $175.00. It is the intention of the hospital authorities to have it "boarded off" their inventory as unserviceable. The Rev. Principal has stated that he can put this in repair and would like to have the Department purchase it for him. He considers that its outside sale value would be $600 and probably considerably less as it is now placed outside the building exposed to the weather, and deteriorating.

I would recommend that contact be made with the Department of Veterans' Affairs for the transfer of this equipment to the school as I am informed that there is likely to be some keen competition for local purchase of the mixer.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, 16 September 1946.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of September 16th, file 153-1-5 (W.T. 1), regarding a 60 Quart Dough Mixer Machine which you are interested in purchasing for the Mission Residential School at Vancouver, B.C., and I regret to inform you that no report of surplus covering this equipment has been received from the Department of Veterans Affairs. I have, however, requested DVA to advise if the machine is available for disposal. Your requirement in this respect has been recorded and a priority directive forwarded to War Assets Corporation, copy of which is attached hereto.

The setting of prices is not a function of this Committee and such enquiries should be directed to the Merchandising Manager, War Assets Corporation, 4095 St. Catherine Street W., Montreal, P.Q. The prices are established either by taking the last price at which a sale of a comparable article was made by the Corporation on the open market or appraisal by representatives of War Assets Corporation (either members of the Corporation staff or competent commercial appraisers who may be selected by the Corporation) or the known going market price.

In view of the fact that no report of surplus has been received, I doubt if the Corporation would be in a position to furnish you a price at this time.

Yours very truly,

E.E. Thompson,
Executive Secretary.

October 7th, 1946.

Mr. J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.

Dear Mr. Gillett;

Several years ago, the Department issued a purchase order, covering a potato peeler to be supplied to the St. Mary's Indian Residential School at Mission, B.C. As the peeler could not be procured at the time, the purchase order was withdrawn. The equipment is procurable now from Ryan Brothers, 633 E. Hastings St., Vancouver, B.C. and is priced at $255.00.

I would be pleased if you would arrange to have a new purchase order issued to cover this item, as it is urgently needed at the school. I believe that the unused portion of our 1946 allotment for repairs and equipment will take care of this expense.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 10th inst., enclosing requisition for equipment requested by the Principal of the St. Mary's Mission Residential School. The particular type of equipment requested by the Principal has not usually been purchased from Parliamentary appropriation.

Recently we submitted to the Minister's office a list of labour saving equipment such as requested by the Principal of the St. Mary's Mission Residential School. As yet we have not received any reply and until the Minister gives a definite decision it is regretted that purchase of such equipment cannot be authorized.

There is approximately $1,100. in the current year's appropriation for St. Mary's Mission School, that is available for repairs and improvements or the purchase of such equipment as we supply. Please consult with the Principal again and let me hear from you regarding the best method of spending the amount available.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Sup't. Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I have been advised about one week ago by Indian Commissioner, Major Mackay, that the Department has kindly authorized the sum of $2700.00 for repairs and equipment at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School for the current year. The sum of $1700 has been marked for repairs etc. and $1000 for the purchase of new equipment.

It appears from a survey of conditions at the school, that the cost of the minimum amount of repairs, urgently needed, will exceed $1700. These repairs are so necessary that I would like to have permission to use part of the $1000, marked for equipment, to take care of the repairs. There is indeed, much equipment that I would like to have, but the repairs are of a much more urgent nature. One item, for instance, covers repairs to our boilers. On a recent trip, the boiler inspector found that our laundry boiler needed retubing and our heating boiler required a new front. This represents about $300 that we did not expect. To give you an idea of how the money is proposed to be spent, I am listing below, our most urgent repairs with their cost:

- Classroom partition...........$198.00
- Linoleum in dining rooms.....$1100.00
- Boiler repairs..................$10.00
- Repairs to roof...............$50.00

Quotations on the first two items have already been sent to the Indian Agent. I am at present working on the others. The classroom partition is indispensable. We have secured an extra teacher and I must
necessarily, provide her with a classroom. Our dining room floors are of soft wood. To keep them clean requires too much scrubbing. Covering these floors with linoleum now will give us long-wearing, easy to keep clean floors. If we let this work go for another year, we will have to renew the wood, even in order to lay linoleum. Moreover the work has to be completed before school opens. The boiler repairs speak for themselves. The roof of the main building is unsightly and long overdue for paint. This work was proposed to be done last year, but it was too late in the season for painting. I trust that this information will assist you in understanding our problem and the reason for my request.

I might also mention that some time ago I applied through the Indian Agent for 24 desks for the senior classroom. Last year some of the pupils were using benches to sit on and tables instead of desks. Many others were uncomfortably crowded into old-fashioned double desks. Even last autumn I requested desks while on a visit to the Commissioner's office. At the time there was some hope of getting some that had been discarded by another school, but I never heard another word about them and we got along as best we could. Now, I understand that if we get these desks, recently ordered, the cost will be taken out of the new equipment grant. I was always under the impression that such equipment, so fundamental to a classroom, would be supplied by the department as school supplies. I would be glad to have your opinion on this matter.

I would appreciate your reply by airmail as there is not much time left in which to make decisions about the above matters.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal.

Dear Mr. Gillett;

I am enclosing in triplicate, a quotation of the Patterson Boiler Works, Vancouver, B.C. covering the retubing of our laundry boiler and other repairs as stated on the quotation. We were instructed to have this work done by the government boiler inspector.

Inasmuch as this work had to be done in the shortest possible time, I found it impossible to secure any quotation other than this one from the Patterson Boiler Works. At first a tentative quotation of $523.00 was made by the Company. However, after the boiler was dismantled at the school and a thorough examination made, it was found that certain parts were intact that might have been found faulty; consequently, an amended quotation of $490.00 was submitted. Considering the size of the job, I have found the Patterson Company to be most co-operative and anxious to help us in this emergency.

I would be very grateful if you would arrange for the approval of this work as soon as possible. It is imperative that there be speedy action taken if we are to have the laundry in operation for the opening of school.

Very sincerely,

Dear Mr. Gillett;

I am enclosing herewith quotation in triplicate from the Patterson Boiler Works Ltd. of Vancouver, covering repairs to the front of our main heating boiler. This work was urgently recommended by the boiler inspector on his visit of inspection to the school last June. This firm has done excellent work on our laundry boiler and while they were here on that job, they took the time to thoroughly inspect and estimate the repairs necessary on the heating boiler. In order to keep the cost down to a minimum, I am prepared to supply the fire brick and accommodation for the workmen.

I would be very pleased if you would arrange to have this work completed as soon as possible.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Thanking you for your kind consideration, we remain,

PATTERSON BOILER WORKS LIMITED.

Manager,

February 23, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I desire to refer to your letters of the 12th instant, file 8-11-4 (153) with reference to unpaid accounts for materials purchased for the Kootenay School. As you are aware, this is a church-owned school and consequently we should not exceed the amounts specifically provided in the current year's appropriation.

However, in the case of St. Mary's Mission School, we authorized practically the whole amount provided in the current year's appropriation early in the fiscal year. It was later found necessary to make some urgent repairs to the boilers and we approved the expenditure. At the present time we are endeavouring to secure the additional funds that are needed to pay outstanding accounts and have no doubt that we will secure these but it may be two or three weeks before we can issue cheques.

Outstanding cheques at the moment are,-

Voucher 902 - W.F. Swan $198.75

May 14, 1948.

Dear Father Fleury:

An amount of $2,700.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements and purchase of new equipment at the St. Mary's Mission Residential School.

Due to the fact that there was more expended at this school last year than was actually provided, it was necessary to hold three accounts, amounting to $726.75 and pay them from the current year's appropriation. This leaves an amount of $1,973.25. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Indian Commissioner Arneil and you should consult him regarding the best manner in which to spend the amount mentioned.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan

July 3, 1948.

W. S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B. C.

St. Mary's Indian Residential School needs the following repairs:

1. A new floor for small girl's dormitory. Floor is badly worn and needs to be completely recovered. This should be done in the summer holidays. Material will cost $195.00 as per tender enclosed from Campbell Builders Supplies Limited, Mission City, B. C.

2. Repairs to Dorad heater. This is for central hot water system which supplies the school buildings, preventorium and staff building. Material will cost $99.00 as per tender enclosed from Fred Welsh & Son, Vancouver, B. C.

I recommend that this be approved, and that material be purchased from Campbell Builders Supplies Limited and Fred Welsh & Sons.

J. Gillett
Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to Supt. Gillett's letter of July 3rd attached, I would recommend that the Department approve an expenditure of $195 for materials for a new floor in the small girls' dormitory, St. Mary's Residential School, and an expenditure of $95.00 for repairs to the Dorad heater at the school. It is presumed that these amounts will be chargeable to the appropriation for St. Mary's school this year.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Gillett:

I am enclosing herewith an estimate for repairs to our Laundry Extract Basket, amounting to $454.00. Also find enclosed receipt for sum of $280.00 as part payment from St. Mary's School on above bill.

This was a repair that was badly needed and most urgent. To allow the machine to remain in its broken condition would have endangered the lives of the Sisters and the children working in the Laundry. To wait for repairs to be made would have held up our laundry for weeks and at the same time added many hours of extra labour and heavy labour upon the children. I felt that the only thing to do was to get the work done at once. Through the U and I Tinner I had the repairs done and the machine working in four days.

I am asking therefore, that this bill of $454.00 come out of the grant for expenditures and repairs, and that payment be made as follows: a refund of $280.00 to St. Mary's School and a payment of a further $174.00 to the U and I Tinner, listed herein.

I received sometime ago, an OK for an expenditure of some $800.00 for wash basins and new toilets. As I find now that delivery of these cannot be promised or assured, I would ask that this expenditure be cancelled.

Sincerely yours,

(sgd) John W. Hennessy OMI

I recommend that this be approved.

Dear Mr. Gillett:

In reply to your request I am listing below the estimates for repairs and equipment for St. Mary's Indian Residential School for this year.

A. A needed piece of equipment for Laundry is a Tumbler Dryer. Lack of drying space plus weather conditions here at Coast makes drying of clothes a long tedious job. Estimated cost of Dryer is about $700.00

B. Likewise needed in Laundry is a Rotary Washer. Present equipment is old and worn and much too small to serve needs of 210 children. Machines are set in motion at 6.30 in morning and work is not completed until 5 at night. Estimated cost of Washer $1000.00

C. Floors in both Laundry and Drying Room are badly worn. Can no longer be repaired and keep both rooms cold. Estimated cost of rough flooring (work to be done by School) is about $150.00

D. Toilet facilities are poor in Boys building especially in the Dormitory, where 8 toilets must serve 105 boys. Also some repairs and replacements are needed for present toilets in Boys and girls buildings. Estimated cost of new equipment and repairs about $250.00

E. There are many repairs to be made to Buildings and Classrooms. Girls Building is looking shabby and trim must be painted; floor in Sewing Room should be sanded and oiled at once; some inside painting and repairs to Girls Building; also two classrooms to be painted inside and out. We would supply the labour for this work; estimated cost of materials about $500.00

From your recent visit and inspection of School, I am sure that you will agree that these repairs and equipment are urgently needed, both as an economic measure and for health and wellbeing of the children.

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Phelan:

On the occasion of your recent visit to St. Mary's, we spoke of the needs of our gymnasium, and of a means of enlarging it. As you are aware, our present gymnasium is but a converted root cellar. Its floor space, and its ceiling height are woefully inadequate to cope with the needs of some 102 boys and 112 girls. Gymnastic sports contribute much to the health and morale of a school. Here on the Coast, where the winter season and early spring are damp and wet, a gymnasium is most essential. And here at St. Mary's, where the efforts of a loyal and courageous staff, have built up a very fine health and physical education programme, a gymnasium is in order, as the Department has turned down repeated requests in the past to build a new gymnasium and auditorium. I would ask that a grant in aid to enlarge present gymnasium be made. At the cost of $800.00, a new floor could be laid in the gymnasium, a makeshift stage be removed which occupies much floor space, and a leanto be built onto the end of the gymnasium which would serve the needs of a stage or auditorium. For a stage we must have to carry on the plays and concerts which are a part and necessary part of any school. In connection with this request and in proof of the fine physical education programme established here, four of the older girls and three of the older boys are able to take complete charge of the physical training required by the B.C. curriculum. Further I believe St. Mary's is one of the few Indian Schools having an Indian boy graduate as full time P.T. instructor on its staff.

I feel therefore that this request deserves the earnest consideration of your Department, who I know are keenly interested in the furtherment of health and physical programmes in the Schools.

Very Sincerely,

[Signature]
John W. Hennessy O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Gillett:

Last week our laundry mangle burnt out. Upon enquiry I find that it is beyond repair, this machine being over 30 years in use. The loss of the Mangle is an added burden to the already difficult task of washing and laundry. Not only does it prolong this task many hours, it adds much extra work upon the children. For this Mangle does the work of twenty hand irons. Due to our full day class programme all washing must be done on Saturday. I feel this task should be made as simple and quick as possible in order to give the children engaged some relaxation after a full weeks class. I am therefore enclosing in duplicate a quotation on a new Mangle, from a leading and reliable Agency in Vancouver. I respectfully ask that this expenditure be authorized from grant made to St. Mary's School for repairs and expenditures during present year.

Hoping that you will do all possible to help realize this needed purchase, I remain

Sincerely yours,

Dear Mr. Gillett:

In reply to your enquiry re estimates for needed repairs and equipment at St. Mary's School, I submit the following:

1). New Washing Machine for Laundry:
Present washing machines are badly worn and impossible to repair or keep in order. Further they are too small for the work at hand, having only together a capacity of 70 lbs dry wash. This results in a long and tiring day for the children, sometimes carrying well into the evening. I enclose quotation from Stanley Brock Co., for washing machine with capacity of 115 lbs dry wash, motor driven at price of $125.00, f.o.b. Mission. This seems an excellent machine and should cut washing time by 30% or more.

2). Paint for Classrooms etc.
Paint is needed for Grades 5, 6, 7, 8, classrooms, both inside and out. For trim on Convent and Dining room building; fire-escapes badly rusted; one staff room in convent; bathrooms in boys and girls buildings. I submit estimate from reliable firm in Mission City and also from firm in Vancouver; one for $97.00, and the other for $37.00.

3). Flooring for Dormitories.
Condition of floor in Junior and Midget Dormitory is poor. Floor is badly worn, very hard to keep clean and impossible to paint. The only remedy seems to be a new floor. I enclose quotations from two firms in Mission. One for $208.00, and the other for $420.00.

4). New Stoker for Hot Water System.
I enclose quotation for new Stoker for Hot water, already installed, through kind permission of the Department, when old Stoker broke down. Cost of Stoker installed is $35.00.

I will forward estimates for Sports equipment; leather for Craftwork; boiler repairs as demanded by Inspector; needed toilet repairs as soon as received.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
John Whiteman
Principal

VICTORIA, B.C., May 2, 1929.

Dear Sir:

Could you kindly inform me as to the prospects for the building of a new school at Mission at an early date to replace the old one? I am asking this for the reason that the accommodation for manual training at present is very poor and if a new school is not to be built this year, then I think we ought to put up another outside building to be used for manual training purposes. The outside class room recently erected would be admirably suitable as a manual training room when not required for class room work, but if there is no hope of getting a new school started during the present year, then, as above stated, I feel it would be advisable to erect another outside building for manual training purposes which would cost approximately $1,000.00.

Your obedient servant,

WED/KD.

W. E. Ditchburn

You might inform the Reverend Principal that a temporary arrangement should be made for the manual training activity.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that I have taken over St. Mary's Residential School from Reverend E. Maillard, and have commenced the School year with a full pupil list. In addition, we have forty applications which we cannot accept for want of accommodation.

As you are perhaps aware, I have been a Field Missionary in this territory for some time, and have a thorough local knowledge of all the Reserves our pupils are drawn from, which will, I hope, be of advantage in my present capacity of Principal.

It is my most earnest wish to co-operate with the Department in the fullest possible manner, and to carry out the views for Indian education laid down. To do this effectually, however, I feel that I must draw your attention to the condition of the School buildings, and the urgent need there is of a new School.

I know of course, and thoroughly appreciate the efforts you have made to have this carried out and in opening the matter afresh, I merely wish to add my mite to the weight of evidence prepared by the Department in support of the undertaking.

Apart altogether from the deplorable living conditions we have to contend with in the dormitory portions of the School, I would stress the fact that the Laundry became so dangerous the late Principal was obliged to erect a new building at a cost to the School of $1,032.00. This work was performed in such manner that it can be moved later on and applied to some suitable purpose.

At the present moment there is no building for Manual Training and as the School has already undertaken, in connection with the laundry, all the expense its finances will bear this year, I would most urgently ask that the Department assist us to this extent, in order that the Training Course may be commenced under flight conditions, as my finances will not admit of the construction of a proper building.

Yours truly,

T.J. Fahlman.
Principal.

Under date of February 20th, 1929, Mr. W.E. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner for B.C., sent a Manual Training Equipment to this School and at the same time addressed a letter of instructions to the late Principal.

Sir:

SIR:-

In reply to your letter dated 23rd of February, File No.153-1-11, I beg to inform you that the name of the temporary instructor in manual training engaged at the St. Mary's Mission Residential School, is James McCurrach of New Westminster, B.C.

As regards his qualifications, these are practical rather than technical, as he has been working with contracting carpenters right along. Owing to the depression at present existing he is filling in his time at Mission, and so far has given every satisfaction. I need hardly point out that it is extremely difficult to obtain an instructor without paying him accordingly, and Mission School is absolutely unable to do so at present.

I hired the man myself and sent him there at $50.00 a month and board, in order that the regulations of the Department regarding manual training might be carried out. The School will board him, but they have no money to do it now, therefore, really think the Department should allow $50.00 for this service under the circumstances. If this man stays he will take the technical training course in the summer, and come in line with other Instructors employed by the Department, but for the time being this is the only arrangements possible to make.

While upon this subject, I would most earnestly draw the attention of the Department to the absolute necessity of a new School at Mission. Years have gone by since it was first promised, and I would like to remind the Department that were it not for this promise, the Reverend J. Duplanil, now at Kamloops School, would have repaired Mission School, so that it would have been safe for a good many years to come.

This Winter has passed without any catastrophe on account of its extreme mildness, but I absolutely refuse to assume any responsibility for anything that may happen to the School and pupils in future. I have warned the Department time after time, and feel that I have done all I can in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

R.C.M. Daunt.
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario:

Dear Sir:

Some time ago I sent in to our Agent a requisition for Technical School material,—the carpentry department. In the last fourteen months with all the building program here I have used a great deal of lumber which I bought from the Alberta Lumber Company in Vancouver after I had found their prices better than those submitted by the local lumber yard, the Maple Ridge and the Fraser Mills Companies. Quite naturally when setting prices for this requisition I went to them and mentioned my need to procure the materials on the list. They figured on it and it was their figure I sent with my requisition.

Yesterday I received a letter from the Agent stating that he had received authority to make the purchase, and adding that the purchase should be made from a firm on the approved list. He gives a list of the approved concerns and I find that the "Alberta" is not on it. Now, I had no knowledge of the existence of such a list; I had no political reason for dealing where I dealt, my reason was an economic one solely. Neither do I know the strictness of the necessity of adhering to this list, and therefore I make the request that permission be granted in this case to purchase this material from the Alberta Lumber Company.

This Company has been very obliging to me in every way; their service has been above reproach and the quality of their lumber unexcelled, and they have been especially considerate in allowing me credit. For these reasons and for the fact that I unwittingly acquainted them of our immediate and urgent need of this material and obtained their prices, I would appreciate it as a personal favour if I were allowed to put the little deal through with them. Should the permission be refused me, I fear my credit with this Company to which I am very considerably indebted may be adversely affected.

Trusting that this matter will not give you too much trouble, and hoping for an early reply, I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

Gentlemen:

We have received your letter of Nov. 17th and regret that the invoice enclosed was not clear to the Department at Ottawa.

We have rechecked this invoice and find that the extensions are correct, but apparently the terms used in the lumber trade were not clearly understood by them.

The item of 320 Lin. Ft. 2x4, taken for example, was as follows:
320 Lin.Ft. 2x4 - 8/20' # 1x2 Clear Fir $45 - $14!
This does not mean that 8 pieces 20' long were shipped, but is a lumbermen's term meaning that 320 Lin. Ft. made up of different lengths between 8 and 20' were shipped. This term is used to differentiate from 3/7', which means 3' to 7' only, and takes a different price range.

To make the invoice more clear for the Department at Ottawa we have made up a copy showing the number of pieces and the lengths of each item shipped from our tally cards.

We trust this will be satisfactory and in future will be careful to show all details when making invoices.

Yours very truly,

SIR:-

I beg to forward you herewith, estimates for lumber requirements in connection with Manual Training classes at St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, and which come to $345.42.

An application for various tools and hardware, in connection with these classes, amounting to approximately $250.00, according to the estimate from Messrs. Gordon & Belyea Limited is also enclosed.

St. Mary's Mission Residential School is making great strides in its Manual Training classes and deserves to be encouraged. Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th inst. regarding
the order placed by the Department with McLenman, McFeely & Prior
Ltd. of Vancouver for equipment for the manual training class
of this School. I received the purchase order, which you forwarded
to me on November 28, and have checked the articles as they have
been delivered to us.

The reason why I have not yet forwarded to the Department
the invoices which the Company has sent to me is that the order
has not yet been completely filled. I received invoices dated
Dec. 6th, 7th, 17th, 21st, Jan. 4th. Of the articles received
and listed on those invoices I had to report shortages. On Dec. 6th,
the Company wrote me saying that five items would be sent later,
some in December and the remainder in January. To date three of
those have not been delivered. I do not know what has been the cause
of the long delay. I will go to see the Company personally on my
next trip to Vancouver in a few days and when all the goods have
been delivered and the invoices received I will send the latter to
you properly checked and certified.

May I take this occasion to thank you personally for the
special Grant allowed by the Department for the re-construction
of the water reservoir for the School. The work was very ably
carried out by the contractor Mr. W.H. Swan of Hatzic B.C. We
will have an abundant supply of water now, both for domestic
purposes and for any fire emergency.

Again thanking you I am,

Yours very truly,

F. O'Grady O.M.I.
Principal.

Dear Mr. Hoey;

I have received your letter of March 30th, wherein you enclosed certain invoices of McLennan, Feely & Prior, covering tools and equipment for the vocational training class at St. Mary's School. Father O'Grady has been transferred to the Kamloops school and I have taken the matter up with him and he advises me as follows, regarding the equipment referred to in your letter.

You will note on the original purchase order the items, one drill press and one mortising attachment, are requested as complete, thus necessarily covering the chisels, bits and bushings, which are essential for the operating of these machines. McLennan, McFeely & Prior did not send these pieces with the equipment and naturally Father O'Grady advised them so, with the consequence that they were delivered. The fact that they were not included in the other account appears to be due to an oversight on the part of the firm, since they should be quite aware of the fact that the drill press and the mortising attachment are unoperable without the chisels etc. If you will kindly refer to our requisition you will note that these items were requested inasmuch as they were asked for complete.

On the invoice copy, which I am enclosing for your convenience in re-checking this matter there are two items which do not enter into the question. The #9547 4-step cone pulley, which, although necessary, may be excluded and the #976 chisel holder, which is cancelled by a credit note. The other items, without exception, are essential operating parts of the drill press and the mortising attachment and consequently I feel that I am justified in referring this matter again to you. My opinion is that the firm of McLennan, McFeely & Prior are at fault, inasmuch as they did not recognize from the original requisition that the drill press and the mortising attachment were requested as complete.
I trust that the above information will be of service in taking this matter up with the firm.

Very Sincerely Yours,

A. H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I am enclosing herewith, quotations covering supplies and material urgently needed for our vocational training.

The estimate from the Valley Lumber Yards, in the amount of $197.80 covers lumber that will be needed for the training of the school children, as well as for several projects that we have had in mind for the past two years. We could never begin these projects because we had been unable to get supplies of manual training lumber.

The quotation from Marshall-Wells B.C. Limited, covers small tools which are needed both in the carpenter's shop and plumbing shop. At present we have not enough for the use of the children.

I would be very pleased if you would assist us in procuring these items.

Yours sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.,
Principal.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF H. H. MacKenzie,
School Inspector, following his inspection of the
ST. MARY'S MISSION INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
May 2 and 3, 1945.

Vocational Training:

Boys: Manual training divided into two groups, seniors and juniors. Seniors follow department course as far as possible; are trained in the use of planes, saw hammer; also on wood lathe and drill press. They assist in the construction of small buildings; measuring and estimating lumber; mixing concrete, etc. Juniors are trained in the use and care of tools; their purpose; and do simple operations in construction of small articles.

Cobbling: About twelve boys are trained in the cobbling shop, learning to repair shoes and leather articles. So far this year they have repaired about two hundred pairs of shoes.

Stationary Engineering: Six chosen boys work with the school engineer learning the operation and maintenance of boilers. Emphasis is laid on safety and the correct reading of gauges.

Dairying: The boys excel in this work and are trained thoroughly in the care and upkeep of dairy cattle. Our junior Calf Club won the B.C. Trophy last fall.

Farming: Boys are given a complete course in all branches of farming; care and use of farm machinery, rotation of crops, etc.

Logging: Older boys assist in simple logging operations, mainly to emphasize safety methods as many of them find work when they graduate in logging camps. In spite of the high accident rate in these camps, not one of our boys has been injured since these instructions started.

Mission City, B.C. March 14th, 1946.

The Indian Agent,
New Westminster Agency,
New Westminster, B.C.

Dear Sir;

To further the technical training at the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, we are in need of several pieces of equipment, such as a forge and acetylene welding kit. At the present time our technical training has been mostly limited to woodworking as we had no equipment or tools for metal work. Moreover I had no competent instructor. I have been fortunate in securing the services of a highly trained man, who is in a position to instruct our senior boys in blacksmithing and welding. He is a former employee of the school and now a returned soldier. While in the army he completed several courses in metal work and I am anxious that he begin his instructions to the boys as soon as possible. This training should be of great value to the Indian boys; fitting them for employment and enabling them to do their own repair work at home. Eventually we would need additional equipment for the School shop, but for the present, to get things started, we have immediate need of the two above items. Since the Department has always shown such a keen interest in the technical training of the boys, I would request that they purchase the forge and welding kit for use in training the boys. The following prices for immediate delivery have been secured from the Marshall Wells Co. Vancouver, B.C.

1- Welding outfit with Cutter........ 113.30
1- Blacksmith forge #0728H.......... 35.25

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I., Principal.
NEW WESTMINSTER, B.C.
March 15th, 1946.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

I beg to forward you herewith, a letter, in duplicate, received from Reverend A.H. Fleury, Principal of St. Mary's Indian Residential School, in which he requests the Department to supply the School with a Welding Outfit and Blacksmith Forge.

Training in blacksmithing and welding should be valuable to the pupils of the School, and I would recommend the purchase by the Department.

I understand that the Reverend Principal discussed this matter with you on a recent visit to your office.

J.D. Caldwell,
Acting Indian Agent.

Enc.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I am forwarding Mr. Acting Agent Caldwell's letter of March 15th and letter dated March 14th from the Principal, St. Mary's Residential School, in connection with the proposed supply of a welding outfit and blacksmith forge, for technical training at the school. I agree with the Principal's views with respect to the value of such training and concur in the Agent's recommendation that this equipment be supplied. The estimated cost is approximately $150.00 and the expenditure could be made a charge against the Technical Education division of the B.C. Special Vote of 1946-47 fiscal year.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Encl.
Ottawa, March 27, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 18th instant,
enclosing a request from the Principal of the St. Mary's
Mission Residential School for certain pieces of equipment.

The Department has no objection to the
purchase of the blacksmith forge, because even younger boys
can make some use of this. However, after giving the matter
very careful consideration, we cannot see our way clear to
authorizing the acetylene welding outfit. There are few, if
any, boys in this school over 16 years of age, and we feel
that it would be hazardous to allow young children to use
such an outfit.

Philip Phelan,

Mr. P. Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

When Mr. Doucet visited our school some months ago, he was greatly impressed by our course in automotive and farm mechanics. This course is given to selected older pupils and has produced great results. Our instructor is a well qualified man, a veteran of the last war, who specialized in mechanics while in the army. We have found that the boys take exceptional interest in this work, and I believe it to be of the highest practical value to them.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa

Re: St. Mary's School - Vocational Training

Attached is letter received from the Reverend Father J.W. Hennessy, Principal of the above-mentioned school, requesting an increase in the grant towards the salaries of the instructors employed for vocational training.

Inspector Davey has reported favourably on the work of the Instructor conducting the course in Farm Mechanics and feels that this type of work is of considerable value to the pupils who are enrolled at this residential school. It is also understood that Mr. Doucet has seen this class in operation and was favourably impressed. In addition to the Farm Mechanics course, instruction is also given in Carpentry.

It would appear that the request of the Reverend Principal is most reasonable and I would recommend that the grant of $50.00 per month now being paid by the Department be increased to $100.00 per month.

November 25, 1948
P.O. BOX 494,
MISSION CITY, B.C.

Mr. J. Gillett
Superintendent, Indian Agency
New Westminster B.C.

Dear Mr. Gillett:

One of the most popular and beneficial courses conducted here in School, is the course in Farm Mechanics. This course is given to a selected group of the older pupils in Grades 7, 8, 9. Our instructor, Mr. T. Veres, a veteran of the last war, holds a Master Mechanics rating, with 12 years experience in Automotive Mechanics, Welding, and Tinsmithing. He has been at the school for 10 years or more, and so knows the Indian boys. The Course followed is that outlined by the Programme of Studies for Industrial Arts in Junior High.

To obtain the services of our instructor we have had to pay him a good monthly salary. This has added to the costs of running the School. The results have been so beneficial, the Course so interesting and Practical, the vocational training so well adapted to the natural ability of Indian boys, that I feel the Course merits every encouragement. At present, the instructor is being paid at the rate of $75.00 monthly. I would respectfully request that the Department provide a monthly sum of $100.00 as their share. In view of the fact that the monthly grant for Manual Training only partly covers cost of salary for same, I feel the sum requested for the Farm Mechanics Course is not extravagant. I would be very pleased if you would take this matter up with Mr. Arneil so that necessary steps may be taken for granting of my request.

Hoping this matter be brought to a satisfactory issue,

Sincerely yours,

John W. Hennessy
OMI

Re: St. Mary's Indian Residential School. Your file 8-11-6 (153)

Owing to the absence of Mr. Doucet from Head Office on Departmental business, we have been delayed in making a reply to your letter of April 1st regarding the requisitions you forwarded for home economics supplies at the above school.

Your letter does not state if the school has a teacher suitably qualified for teaching this subject. We do not want to discourage teaching home economics at this school, but we feel that the above information should have been supplied and that we should have been informed regarding the room that is available for the home economics class.

In order not to delay the matter unnecessarily, it has been decided to authorize an expenditure not exceeding $200.00 for equipment. We feel that this amount should be sufficient for a start, especially in view of the fact that the equipment requested is more than is actually needed at the present time.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing a copy of a Voucher I forwarded to our Supt., here, together with the Quarterly Returns for the School. In so acting, I wish to make it clear that I had no intention of appearing forward or demanding. I was prompted to this action from the knowledge that both the High School at Kamloops and the High School at Cranbrook have been receiving this extra yearly grant towards care and keep of the High School children. Just why St. Mary's was never included in this I do not know. There are many extra expenses incurred in running the High School branch of the School. There is the matter of a High School teacher—this year we will have two teachers—whose salary is naturally quite high. Then in the matter of clothing, the High School pupils need something a little different from the general run of the School. Most of our High School boys and girls participate in outside activities such as Gymnastic displays; folk dancing; extra-mural sports etc. On these occasions they are mingling with other High School children and I have felt that in the matter of clothing, expenses etc., nothing should be left undone which would give our Indian children a feeling of inferiority. A High School demands a high standard in every way. To maintain this standard is indeed an extra matter of work and expense.

In what way either Kamloops or Cranbrook incur expenses not felt here, and so warrant the extra grant denied to us, I do not understand. I feel therefore that my request is within reason and do hope that you will do whatever possible to help us out in this matter. Our High School is progressing very well. I expect about 20 pupils in Grades 9, 10, and 11, this coming fall.

Thanking you, I remain

Sincerely yours

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Leonard J. Allen, Pupil No. 364, of the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School at Muncie, who died at Muncie Memorial Hospital (place) on May 18th, 1935.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir:

I was first called to attend Gordon Jr. at Harrison Mills at the home of Mr. Halls, his grandfather on Nov. 17th. He and his sister had fever, abdominal pain, and general malaise. To me it looked like gastro-intestinal flu. I advised castor oil and enemas which apparently relieved him of his symptoms. The aunt noted that there were apple seeds in the stool and said that he had been eating frozen apples. Apparently he recovered from this and I was again notified on Nov. 17th. Then he had a lower left lobe congestion (of the lung) with a pleurisy. Advised the usual foulness—expectorants etc., and saw him on the 19th and 23rd and then his condition had improved and he was well on the way to recovery but on Dec. 3rd I was again called and the opposite base was congested. The family gave the history that he had got out and two nights before and got very cold. This second infection...
lasted from Dec 3 to Dec 7th when he died. The cause of death being an pneumonic condition of the lower left lobe of the lung. The infective agent being the influenza bacillus and the contributory cause being the initial infection of the lower right lobe.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated the 17th instant, File No.153-1-23, in which you request me to fill out Form No.414, in connection with the death of Gordon Joe, pupil No. 430, St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, registered at Seabird Island Reserve, Lytton Agency, who died at home on the 8th of December, 1935.

This boy does not belong to the New Westminster Agency, and I was unaware of his death until the School Quarter Return was submitted at the beginning of January.

I, however, got in touch with Doctor P.S. McCaffrey, Medical Officer for the Seabird Island Indians, and am enclosing herewith, his report, which I trust will cover the case.

Apparently the boy was sickly at School, and his father took him home, so that his actual final illness was entirely outside the control of the School, and it would, therefore, appear that Form No.414 does not apply.

Your obedient servant,

A.O.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Enclosed is an application from Mrs. Ethel G. Castleman for employment in the Nanaimo Hospital School. Mrs. Castleman has been sent the new application form and as soon as it is received will be forwarded.

She was employed at the Indian Day School at Gitlakdamix in September 1946 transferring to Port Simpson in January 1947.

Inspector Devey has not inspected her work, but Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's reports indicate that she has done satisfactory work.

Dr. P.S. Tennant, Regional Supervisor, Indian Health Services, has informed me that he has recommended the employment of a Miss O'Connor as teacher at the Nanaimo Hospital. As she is a Catholic it has been suggested to him that Miss O'Connor would be better used as a replacement for Miss Ethel McGrand, formerly teacher at the Coqualeetza Hospital. Under date of July 21st District School Inspector Davey forwarded a requisition for supplies for the Nanaimo Indian Hospital school. MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury.

Re: School No. 900.

In his letter of March 6, 1936, Dr. Truesdell, Indian Agent, advises the Department that, owing to ill health, Sister M.A. Gamache has been forced to give up duties as teacher of the Fort Simpson Indian Day School and that Sister Gadbois has taken charge of the school. September 8th, 1936.

MEMORANDUM

Representative of the Treasury.

Re School No. 900

Rev. Sister M. A. Gamache has succeeded Sister Gadbois as teacher of the Fort Simpson R. C. Indian Day School from September 1st, 1936.

The following entry should, therefore, appear on the September pay list:

900 - Sister M. A. Gamache - Fort Simpson, - $65.00 N. W. T.

Sister Gamache's services will be continuous from Sept. 1, 1936.
Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Fort Simpson R.C. Day School, No. 900.

Please note that Sister McQuillan gave up duties at this school at the end of October and no further salary should be paid to her. She has been succeeded by Sister Mary Olive Sarrasin from November 1, 1943, at a salary of $65.00 a teaching month. As soon as the necessary forms are received from Sister Sarrasin I will forward them to you.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of August 18, No. 152776-3, has just reached me. I deeply regret the fact of the small attendance at the Fort Simpson Day school which you have mentioned. I am afraid that the breakdown in the health of the Rev. Mr. Blow during the last year was responsible for the irregularity of which you rightly complain. This school has hitherto been one of importance in the education of the Indian and half breed children of the district. Right Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of Your Lordship's letter of the 2nd ultimo, regarding payments of salary to the Rev. J. C. Blow, former teacher of the St. David's Mission, Fort Simpson, Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the last cheques sent, covering the services of Rev. Mr. Blow, were for the quarters ending March 31, and June 30, 1921. A cheque for $100, being the grant allowed for salary for that period was sent on August 18, 1921, to the Imperial Bank of Canada, South Edmonton, for deposit to the credit of the MacKenzie River Diocese. At the same time a cheque was sent the Indian Agent, in favour of the Rev. W. A. Blow, covering the bonus due for the two quarters above mentioned. In this connection I would refer you to our letter of August 18, 1921, and the school was closed until the September quarter, 1922. A cheque has been sent, covering the services of Rev. F. Clark for the September and December quarters, 1922. We were aware that the school was closed from June 30, 1921 to September, 1922. The returns for the March and June quarters, 1923, have not yet reached the Department.

In view of the above, we are unable, from our records, to find that any cheque has been sent to Rev. Mr. Blow, since his bonus cheque on August 18, 1921.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, April 26th, 1927.

Sir,-

On the 14th instant, the Department received a return showing the attendance of Bella Hope and Minnie Tenebah at the St. David's Mission Day School. This is the first return received from this school since June, 1925.

In the past, we allowed payment at the rate of $3. a day for each day that the school was open. The December quarter return stated that the school was open for forty-eight days and a cheque for $144. was issued and sent to the Imperial Bank of Canada, Edmonton, Alta., for deposit to the credit of McKenzie River Diocese. I am informed by the Director of the Northwest Territories and Yukon Branch, Department of the Interior, that a similar return was sent to them but, in view of our payment, they do not intend to make any allowance. Please let me have a full report on this school, stating if you consider, in view of the small attendance, the Department is justified in making any payment. Are you aware why a return containing the same names was sent to both Departments?

Please state, also, if the two children whose names are mentioned in the first paragraph of this letter are recognized as Indians.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier.

After I returned North last fall I sent you a report of the attendance of Indian children at our school for the quarter ending Sept. 30th, 1934, in accordance with your instructions given to me at the personal interview with you when I was in Ottawa, Sept. 11. I have heard nothing from you since and am wondering if you received it. I have written the Treasurer of the Diocese, Archdeacon Little, and he has not received any grant from the Indian Department for our school. Please let me know if this report was received at your office, and if so whether the grant has been sent in to the Diocese.

The Department of The Interior is granting us only $25 per quarter instead of the usual $50 although the average attendance of white and half-breed is over the required average of five. As this grant is less than half the amount we are paying our teacher and as I have made myself personally responsible for her salary you will understand my interest in getting all that is due from the Government.

Although our school is kept open every day except legal holidays the attendance of Indians is very irregular, due to the fact that there the natives are not living in the Fort. We try however to encourage them to attend while here even for a short visit. There were a few attending early in this quarter but none at present. I have asked the teacher to make out the report for this quarter and shall enclose it with this letter.*

I hope the Department will recognize our efforts on behalf of their native wards and will make our school the usual grant at least for the quarters when there were Indian children in attendance.

Yours sincerely,

Franklin Clarke

* There were no Indians attending the quarter ending Dec. 31/34.

Fort Simpson, N.W.T., Feb. 12, 1937.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of 3rd November, file 135-5-3, in connection with Fort Simpson C. of E. Indian Day School (St. David's Mission) for period ending August 7th, 1936.

I would like to say that this school has been kept open each Summer since my arrival in Fort Simpson in 1926 by the Minister in charge of the Church of England Mission here.

All the children mentioned in the report are Indians whose parents come to the Fort in Summer for their Annuity payment and remain to fish and hunt from the Fort. This is the only opportunity that some of these children have of receiving a little education, as many Indians are much averse to sending their children to school. Some years this school has been kept open for over two months, but last Summer was exceptional, as fewer Indians stayed in the Fort due to the scarcity of rabbits and fish, and left the Fort shortly after the Treaty payment.

Rev. H.G. Cook has been in charge of this school since the Summer of 1935 and is a B.A. of Western University, and engaged for this Parish by Bishop Sovereign who is in charge of the Diocese.

I may also say that this school is kept open from early in September until the following June each year, and is attended by the children of Halfbreeds, Indians and Whites, and is thus a benefit to the whole community.

The matter of keeping this school open was taken up with Dr. H.W. McGill on his visit here July 31, 1935, by Rev. Franklin Clarke, the then Incumbent and myself, and Dr. McGill then agreed that some compensation was due the Mission for their work in connection with the school.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6471, file 901-4, part 1)
Ottawa, February 7, 1924.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the December quarter return of the Fort Smith Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for $150.00 for salary due for the months of October, November and December is being made payable and sent to Rev. J. C. Lefebvre, O.M.I., Edmonton, ALTA.

The last previous return received from this school was for the quarter ending March 31st, last.

Please advise if this school was in operation during the June and September quarters and, if so, the usual returns should be forwarded in order that any salary or bonus due may be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Brier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

G. Card, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Smith,
N.W.T.
Sir,

I reply to your letter of the 7th, instant, I beg to state that the Fort Smith Day School was not in operation during the June-September quarter. The Reverend Sister Gadbeis tells me that there was sickness prevalent during the first part of the quarter and the balance was covered by the usual summer vacation period.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Agent.

Russell F. Ferrier, Esq.

Ottawa, April 22, 1925.

Reverend Sir,

The Department has just received the March quarter return of the Fort Smith Indian Day School and cheques for salary and bonus due the teacher are being forwarded to the usual address.

I would point out that we have not yet received the returns for the quarters ending September 30, 1924, and December 31, 1924. Please communicate with the teacher at once and arrange for having the necessary forms sent, provided the school was in operation. If the school was not in operation during the quarters mentioned above, you should advise the Department to that effect.

Your obedient servant,

If the school was not in operation please advise the Department as soon as possible to that effect.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit my report of Treaty trip 1939.

Fort Mac Pherson

June 26th.

The meeting was held on the 26th in the Chief's house as agreed and the main subject brought up was their desire for a school of their own at MacPherson, stating that their children all get sick at Aklavik and on being sent home get better, that they will supply the logs and build the necessary buildings, as well as bend all efforts to supply as much food as possible if the department will supply the teachers and their keep. There are now approximately seventy children of school age at the post most of whom have not been to school and they are very adverse to sending them to Aklavik. Ottawa, February 22, 1945.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have discussed with the Director of the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch, Mr. Roy Gibson, the desirability of providing educational facilities for the Indian and half-breed children at Fort McPherson.

The last census shows an Indian population at this point of 407. Of these, 402 are listed as Anglican and five as Roman Catholic. It would appear, therefore, that there must be approximately eighty Indian children of school age at this point.

We are naturally anxious to learn that this matter has been fully discussed with the Anglican bishops concerned. Would the establishment of an Indian Day School at Fort McPherson tend to reduce the enrolment at Aklavik? In view of the fact, however, that the authorized enrolment at this date at Aklavik is only fifty, the effect should not be at all serious.

Would it be possible also to secure from you information with respect to logs and other material available in the district for the construction of a school? The availability of labour locally is also important. Would the Indians be willing to cooperate in the building of a two-room Indian Day School? The construction of such a school, if included in our post-war program, would have to proceed, of course, without any commitment on our part with respect to the establishment of a Residential School later. Our building program is so far behind that it is not at all likely we will be able to secure funds for the construction of Residential Schools at new points at any time during the years immediately ahead of us.

Yours very truly,

Acting Director.

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dep't. of Mines & Resources,

Dear Sir:

I am writing you regarding the educational problems in this place. I would be glad to get certain information from you, and any advice or suggestions you can give me.

First, let me sum up the situation generally as it stands at present. Then I have certain proposals to make.

As you may know, when we first came here eight years ago, we carried on a small day school for seven or eight Indian, half-breed and white children. Mrs. Dewdney, who is a qualified teacher, did the main part of the teaching with myself assisting. We gave the children two to three hours daily. After a couple of years some of our pupils felt themselves too old for school, one or two went to the residential school at Aklavik, and others had moved from the Fort. There were no children of school age among the families resident at the Fort, and it was discontinued. A little later I began to teach a halfbreed child and brought her through the first two grades. Last year I started three more children on primary work.

We could foresee that there would be a number of children ready for school this year, partly because younger families are growing up, partly because one or two families moved into the Fort. Mrs. Dewdney wrote and procured correspondence lessons for these children through the Northwest Territories Branch. We hoped that with the aid of these lessons we could give the children a fair education. Mrs. Dewdney has been taking three children in Grade 3 and one in Grade 5 for an hour and a half a day. I have been taking three beginners for about the same length of time. Two of these children are Treaty Indians. We found the correspondence lessons useful as guides. But we soon found that the parents had not enough education or understanding of methods to be of much help. In spite of this I think the children are going ahead well. Taking the children from October to the end of March, Mrs. Dewdney expects to have pretty well covered the year's work. My beginners are able to read quite well, and should be about three-quarters of the way through the Reader, and about the same distance in Number Work before we have to stop. This is in spite of the fact that all children lost about a month's schooling during the mumps epidemic last fall, and that extra holidays have to be given at mail time, during the times when I am travelling among the camps, and when sickness claims Mrs. Dewdney's attention as Field Matron.

We realise of course, that while the children are getting the three R's, they are missing much of the general knowledge, the training in language and self-expression, the handwork, and the
discipline that are a great part of the value of school life. We feel this is a serious loss. What we are doing is at best a makeshift and does not go far towards giving these children what they need.

Our problem is made the greater by the fact that next year there will be a number more children ready for school. We shall be faced then with a situation which we cannot handle adequately under the present arrangements.

In addition to the families who live at the Fort the whole year, there are several other families for whom something should be done. There are several families, halfbreed and Indian who would like to put their children in day school, and who would move their families into the Fort for the winter if there were a regular school with a qualified teacher. Most of these families speak English in the home. They are not willing for various reasons, to send their children to a residential school. They are willing to go to the trouble and expense of building homes here to see that their children get an education.

I sympathise with them. While some form of residential school seems to be the only solution for Indian children whose parents are usually on the move, I believe that a day school usually produces better results, and that it is greatly preferable where the children are able to attend it regularly.

To let you see the situation in a definite way, I give below a list of families that would have children ready for a day school if one were started next fall. I have divided the list into Treaty and Non-Treaty. Most of the children in the treaty families listed are more white than Indian and speak only English. First, however, I want to meet a possible objection. If a day school were started, might not the attendance again fall off as it did several years ago? Is there any likelihood that such a school could be kept going? I think it could. Most of these families, including the Treaty halfbreeds mentioned above, are native to the district and have their settled traplines near by. These are nearly all young families, with the oldest children eight or nine. From this age they come down in steps of one or two years. The end is nowhere in sight as the wives are young and healthy and likely to have plenty more. I am sure that if we once got started we would have material here for a day school of anywhere from twelve to twenty children or more. In addition I am sure that a number of Indians would leave their families at the Fort if there were a full time school going.

Now I would like to outline the general idea we have in mind if we can obtain help to carry it through.

If possible we want to start a Day School next fall for these children. This school would be in charge of a qualified teacher brought in from "outside" on an adequate salary, would be run for ten months on full school hours, and use the full school curriculum for each grade. It would be the aim to give every child exactly the same education as a white child outside in the same grade would receive.

For the first year at least, school would be held in a large room attached to the Mission which can be adequately heated and lighted (with electricity), and the teacher given board and room at the Mission. The teacher would be found by the Mission, but qualifications would be approved by the Departments concerned who would have control over curriculum, equipment, etc. Only those children would be admitted whose parents would guarantee to keep them at the Fort for the school year. This is necessary to prevent the inconveniences arising from children attending for a few weeks and then leaving. All children would be examined by a doctor in the fall to avoid the presence of T.B. None of the families listed, with one exception (Andrew Kunnizzi) have ever shown any signs of this disease.

Later, when it was proved to the satisfaction of the proper authorities that the scheme was working out, it is hoped that a proper schoolhouse might be erected.
The expenses of the school would be met by grants from the N.W.T. Branch, the Indian Department, and the Hudson's Bay Co. In addition a charge is proposed of $50.00 per child per school year to be paid by all parents.

We feel that the Indian Department, being willing to pay substantial sums for the education of children at the residential schools would be willing to make a grant for any Treaty children who might be attending day school here. By the same mail I am writing to ask the N.W.T. Branch what they would be willing to do on behalf of the non-Treaty children.

The H.B.Co. Manager has two children and expects to be here for some years. The officials of the Company have told me that it is one of their greatest problems to place their men where they can get schooling for their children. I am sure we shall never lack children for the school from this source. As they pay very generous educational grants to their Managers to enable them to send their children out to school, I feel sure they would help generously if we had a school here. Mr. Carson is writing to get definite information on this point by this same mail.

Re the charge of $50.00 per child. This is a prosperous community. None of these families would find any difficulty in paying this sum. I feel they ought to be expected to pay their share. They have all expressed their willingness to do so.

Since we cannot run this scheme without help from these various sources, I am endeavouring to collect here all the information I can. When we get definite word as to what we can expect in the way of support, we shall be able to see whether there is a chance to get it going, and I then propose to lay all the facts and figures in definite form before Bishop Fleming and see if we can make a beginning. I ought to have mentioned before that all families with children at McPherson, Indian, halfbreed and white, belong to the Church of England, so there should be no religious complications.

I would appreciate your letting me know what assistance we could count on from your Department, and would be glad of your frank criticisms and advice. As early a reply as is convenient would be a help, as the time is short if we are to make a start next fall.

Yours sincerely,

(Rev) A.S. Dewdney.

I should add that a day school would not interfere with the residential school at Aklavik, nor with one here if it were built at some future date. Rather they would supplement one another, both filling a real need. There are plenty of children here for both.
Ottawa, February 22, 1945.

Dear Doctor Alderwood:

I have discussed with the Director of the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch, Mr. Roy Gibson, the desirability of providing educational facilities for the Indian and half-breed children at Fort McPherson.

The last census shows an Indian population at this point of 407. Of these, 402 are listed as Anglican and five as Roman Catholics. It would appear, therefore, that there must be approximately eighty Indian children of school age at this point.

We are naturally anxious to learn that this matter has been fully discussed with the Anglican bishops concerned. Would the establishment of an Indian Day School at Fort McPherson tend to reduce the enrolment at Aklavik? In view of the fact, however, that the authorized enrolment at this date at Aklavik is only fifty, the effect should not be at all serious.

Would it be possible also to secure from you information with respect to logs and other material available in the district for the construction of a school? The availability of labour locally is also important. Would the Indians be willing to cooperate in the building of a two-room Indian Day School? The construction of such a school, if included in our post-war program, would have to proceed, of course, without any commitment on our part with respect to the establishment of a Residential School later. Our building program is so far behind that it is not at all likely we will be able to secure funds for the construction of Residential Schools at new points at any time during the years immediately ahead of us.

October 5, 1945.

Bishop Fleming of the Arctic called to see you yesterday, Friday, October 5, 1945, and in your absence I had a talk with him, in the presence of Mr. Phelan and Miss Walton.

The Bishop wished to have a Day School built at Fort McPherson with sleeping accommodation for those pupils whose parents were away from the reserve, and for whom there was not accommodation in the School at Aklavik.

Mr. Phelan explained to the Bishop the difficulties in the way of providing such accommodation at the present time, that is that departmental policy is not to build additional residential schools, and that while the accommodation required would not be large, nevertheless it would be in the same class as residential school accommodation.

We informed the Bishop that we would recommend for inclusion in the 1946-47 Estimates a sufficient sum to take care of building a 2-room Day School with accommodation for two teachers.

The Bishop stressed the fact that the foundation should not be a concrete one, that the soil should not be disturbed and that the foundation should be a surface one of logs. The Indians can take out the logs as soon as the Architect advises the size of building he proposes to have erected. It is unlikely that the building could be built by contract, and it would be better to arrange for it on a day labour basis.

The site which the Bishop has in mind is owned by the Hudson's Bay Company, and His Lordship stated that he expected to discuss securing the land from the Hudson's Bay Company with Mr. Cheshire at an early date. The department, of course, would pay for the land.

I understand that Mr. Phelan will prepare the necessary memorandum to the Architect to secure a plan of a suitable building and that he will inform the Architect of the type of building that the Bishop considers should be erected.
We promised the Bishop that we would write to him in time for him to have the logs taken out this winter, and that, if the building was to be built next summer that the materials for its construction would be on the first boat.

You will doubtless wish to discuss this matter with Mr. Phelan more fully, but I thought it advisable to record the Bishop's visit and what transpired.

Acting Director.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re School at Fort McPherson, N.W.T.

Thank you very much for your letter of 6th instant re Indian Day School at Fort McPherson, Northwest Territories. I note with pleasure that you have included in the estimates for next year the sum of $15,000 for its construction and that the plans will be prepared by the Architect of the Branch in due course.

In order to give you helpful information I have written to Fort McPherson asking for such information as they can furnish in connection with construction there. I want to know for example, how the concrete posts under the new Hudson's Bay Company's house have stood the test of the cold weather; what their ideas are regarding a basement; whether the Indian leaders are prepared to promise help in connection with native labour in order that the building may be constructed with as little delay as possible. I have asked also that they decide themselves how much per hour they honestly think they should be paid for this kind of work. This information cannot come to us until after Christmas since the people will not be in the settlement until then but I think that most of the leading men will be there at that time and if we can get them to arrive at a definite decision it will things easier in the summer.

Our idea of construction would be a frame building with two layers of boarding outside with building paper between them then three inch rock wood bats between the studding and then the inside having insulating board. The ceiling should have vapour barrier construction strapping. In our judgement it is very important that attention should be given to the floors as well as the ceilings. On top of the floor joist we would suggest for your Architect to put shiplap (diagonally) then tar paper, then two layers of insulating board, a layer of plywood on top of that and finally linoleum on top of everything.

If there are any other points that the Architect would care to have our ideas about we would be glad to express them but we have
no desire to tell your Architect how he ought to design the building but only to offer helpful suggestions as a result of what we have seen in the North.

With all kind wishes,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have received a reply to my letter sent to our Missionary at Fort McPherson re certain practical points connected with the erection of the building.

First, he informs me that the basement in the new Hudson's Bay Company's house has proved most unsatisfactory and each summer it has been badly flooded. He, therefore, does not recommend a basement.

Secondly, re foundation. He informs me that the concrete posts 10" square and more than 5' in the ground have proved most satisfactory. He further adds that should any shifting occur it is easy with these concrete posts to adjust the building.

Another point which he makes is that he thinks a mistake has been made when the Hudson's Bay Company had their buildings put high above the ground and cannot be banked. This is a small matter and can be attended to when the new building is being erected. He suggested following the Hudson's Bay Company's practice in using "Cupronol" as a protector on the large timbers used in the base of the building.

In reply to my query about the possibility of securing helpers in the erection of the building he suggests two plans. First, to try and get a fairly large number of Indians to help at .50 - .75¢ an hour with the carpenter overseeing them. In this connection he feels that many of the men are quite good at rough lag work but few of them would be able to do the finer work.

The second plan is to only employ a few picked men, who are known to be good workers, and pay them at the rate of $1. an hour. This information has just come to hand and I am forwarding it to you at once.
