During the past six years, no organized day school has been carried on at Ft. McPherson. There have never been more than two or at most, three children resident at the Fort during the period when we had free time to give to teaching. These two or three children, however, we have taken each year for an hour or so a day. Florence McDonald, now in Grade 3, has received all her teaching from us. In 1944-45 there were five children of school age at the Fort, three halfbreed, one white, and one Indian. These children were put on Edmonton correspondence courses, and in spite of a long break due to the mumps epidemic, were taken through approximately half the year's work.

This year it was decided to attempt to run a part-time Day School on a larger scale. This was undertaken for several reasons. Among them:

1. There has been an increasing desire on the part of the Indians to have their children educated, and less willingness to send them to a residential school.

2. It was felt that the Mothers' Allowance would enable many of the men to leave their children at the Fort while they attended to their hunting and trapping.

3. A number of young halfbreed families were reaching school age. These families on the whole have a distinct prejudice against sending their children to residential school.

4. The prospect of a school being built at McPherson next summer made us anxious to do some preliminary work, which would show the need for a day school, and also enable us to get some grasp beforehand of the conditions under which it would work.

During the summer the Indians were told that Day School would be carried on this winter, and that we were willing to take any children whose parents would undertake to keep them at school from Oct. 15th at least until the opening of the rat season (March 1st). They were assured that the health of the children would be checked to minimize the danger of any infections spreading. Twenty-three children were definitely promised, and on that basis, we wrote for the necessary supplies. When we opened school on October 12th, however, only 15 of these children attended. Roy Wright had to move his family to Aklavik as his wife required medical treatment. It was decided at the last minute to send several other children to the Residential School at Aklavik, and one family was not willing to come in till after freezeup.

Supplies having been ordered somewhat too late to catch the plane, and an expected "igloo" not turning up, new arrangements had to be made in a hurry. A large room in the Mission was used for school. As this had to be used for services on Sunday, desks were constructed, two desks of 12 and 16 feet in length, resting on trestles, so that they could be moved outside. Two senior pupils were given small tables at the back of the room. A roll of blackboard cloth, many years old, was discovered and fastened to one wall over a piece of hardboard. An easel was built to hold reading charts. A supply of readers and textbooks was on hand from other years, some other books requisitioned from our son's library, and some borrowed from Aklavik. The children were required to provide their own note books and pencils. But a great deal of material had to be made or typed by hand, particularly sheets for practice reading to take the place of the workbooks, cards for arithmetic drills, phonics practice other things. The preparation of this has taken from one to two hours extra work each day.
At the opening of school there were 16 children, nine of these being Treaty Indians, five from local halfbreed families, and two white children from the Hudson's Bay Co. Of these children only four had ever attended residential school, five had received all their previous teaching from us, and seven had never attended any school before. All spoke English.

The main part of the work was handled by myself. I have never had normal training, but have had some experience of primary work over the years, and the advantage of the advice and assistance of my wife who holds a teacher's certificate. She took over the whole school for half an hour daily for writing, and three of the senior pupils for half an hour on spelling. This was in addition to her ordinary housework and the constant supervision necessary over our son, doing his Grade II by correspondence.

School was held daily from 9.30 to 12.30 with 15 minutes recess. Of this time, ten minutes was usually given to singing, and ten minutes to Bible reading and short religious instruction. The whole of the rest of the time was spent on the three R's, except for the three senior pupils who took spelling, and some language and expression work in connection with their reading. Most children were given assignments to do at home each day.

The pupils were found to be at very different stages. For instance, one boy who had never been at school and could not read a word, was able to start at once to do the equivalent of Grade 3 arithmetic. He had been taught in the classes by Jessie Bonneplume, a graduate of the Carcross school. Some of those in Grade 1 had already done half the year. Three children of 9, 14, and 16, were very retarded mentally, and it is doubtful if they can ever be taught to read fluently. The impossibility of classifying the children in definite groups made the task of arranging the work much more difficult.

We soon saw that wood for the schoolroom stove was going to be a problem. Our own woodpile was short, and there seemed no prospect of more. The natives will not cut or haul wood, even at prices that would have seemed fabulous five years ago. Consequently, I felt justified in asking the parents to provide half a cord of wood for each child at school. An exception was made in the case of one or two widows and old people. In most cases this was readily promised, and most of it was brought or will be bought eventually. Only in one case, that of William Firth, one of the halfbreeds, was a difficulty made over this, but I understand that he intends to bring the wood eventually. Except for this one case, all families have been very cooperative.

Our main difficulty arose over the question of health. Lice were discovered on the head of one of the white children. Mrs. Dewdney, as Field Matron, gave the children a talking to on the matter, we saw that two or three dirty children were cleaned up, and by publicly questioning each child, made sure that each had a weekly bath and change of underwear. It was necessary to assist one poor family to get the clothing and the bedding necessary.

Soon after school started, we began to take the temperatures of the children each day. It had been discovered by Dr. Hayward that many of the school children at Aklavik who seemed in fair health, were running a daily temperature, and in many cases were in the first stages of T.B. and should not be allowed to associate with healthy children. We were anxious to know whether that was the case at McPherson, or whether...
There was a widespread impression here, which we shared, that McPherson was healthier than Aklavik. Dr. Hayward, who was sceptical of this, encouraged us to test the matter. Temperatures of all children were taken daily for three or four weeks, to avoid any chance that a rise might be caused by colds or mumps (which is still going around). We found that of the 16 children, 9 were running a constant daily temperature between 98 and 100. The whole record was forwarded to Dr. Hayward for his consideration and advice. He immediately ordered the exclusion of three of the children, and of five others if they showed signs of a cough. One of these latter was accordingly excluded, but the other four allowed to continue at school. Three of these were children of William Carson. I felt that he should be told of his children's condition, and did so as tactfully as possible (without telling him what the doctor's orders were). He was extremely unpleasant and uncooperative in the matter and accused me of making up the whole thing. Fortunately, the doctor was able to visit us a few days later, and we took all the school children examined by him in their parents' presence. A number of the children were ordered to come to Aklavik for X-ray. Wm. Firth was again somewhat insolent, and the doctor had to tell him plainly that unless the children were X-rayed within a reasonable time, they would not be able to attend school with the others. After the doctor's departure, these children attended school for about a week, and then were suddenly withdrawn without a word of explanation. It was said that he had stated publicly that there was nothing the matter with his children and that he was not sending them down for an X-ray.

Meanwhile, the Carsons, the white family at the H.B.C.O., had been much alarmed at the result of the doctor's investigations, and when it was found that their own children on one or two occasions were running slight temperatures, where they had been consistently normal before, they felt they were running too great a risk in letting their children attend school with the natives, and they withdrew them, and are teaching them at home.

I had offered to take those children whom the doctor had excluded, privately for teaching, and one boy took advantage of this, but the parents of the other three were somewhat upset over the matter, and withdrew the children entirely.

Our school therefore, was now reduced to seven children, and with these we continued for the two or three weeks that remained.

I propose in the New Year, to offer to take on enough beginners to refill the school, provided they can attend till Easter. I hope to have them examined before the term starts, so as to eliminate any who might be suspect beforehand. This will prevent a repetition of our unhappy experience this winter. A further report will be made at Easter time.

Among other conclusions, I would draw this one - that when a full time Day School is begun here, arrangements should be made for every child to be examined and if possible, X-rayed before the term starts, both for the early discovery and prevention of disease, and for the protection of healthy children and a reassurance to their parents.
Fort Norman, N.W.T.

My dear Bishop Fleming:

I desire to refer to your letter of February 22 and previous correspondence with reference to the proposed day school at Fort McPherson.

I have discussed the matter with the Architect in our Surveys and Engineering Branch, and I regret that owing to the large amount of work that he is attempting to handle this year and the further fact that he has experienced difficulty in securing sufficient staff, it will not be possible for him to prepare any plan. Memorandum:

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Proposed Indian Day School at Fort McPherson, North West Territories.

The 1944 census shows that there are 339 Indians at Fort McPherson and 87 children of school age. Right Reverend A. L. Fleming, Bishop of the Arctic, has visited the Department on several occasions during the past few months, urging the erection of a two-room day school at Fort McPherson. An amount of $15,000.00 has been placed in the Appropriation for the fiscal year 1946-47 for the erection of this school.

In view of the large amount of work that the Surveys and Engineering Branch is endeavouring to handle for this branch during the summer of 1946, it has not been possible for them to prepare plans and specifications for the proposed school at Fort McPherson.

Bishop Fleming is thoroughly conversant with conditions at Fort McPherson and he is prepared to proceed with the erection of the building. He has forwarded to us blue-prints of the proposed two-room school, prepared by his Architects, Messrs. Molesworth, Secord and Savage.

In forwarding these blue-prints, Bishop Fleming writes:

"You will note that we have set forth a building of the simplest type using the material which we believe is most easily procured at this time. If it were possible to get three plywood we would prefer to use it instead.

"This design has been made with the idea of meeting the needs of the situation but involving the minimum of expense."
and difficulty of construction."

Bishop Fleming also advises that he knows a qualified carpenter who is prepared to supervise the erection of the building and that Indian labour is available at Fort McPherson.

The Bishop would appreciate it if the Department would authorize him to proceed with the construction of the new school. He expresses the opinion that he can make the necessary preliminary arrangements immediately and points out that the time element is vital to enable him to secure the material required. I feel that unless we accept Bishop Fleming's suggestion there will be no likelihood of erecting this building during the summer of 1946.

I would therefore appreciate it if the Minister would approve authorizing Bishop Fleming to proceed on the understanding that the total cost will not exceed the amount of $15,000.00.

Dear Mr. Hoey: Re Fort McPherson Day School

I beg to send you a brief report regarding the situation pertaining to this matter.

I. The materials for the building have been ordered from the Clark Lumber Company of Edmonton. I telephoned Mr. Brown, the manager, from Calgary and he will do everything possible to see that the complete unit is sent forward in time to go down river by the first boat. II. We engaged an experienced Carpenter who has already worked for us at Aklavik so that we have every confidence that the building will be taken in hand properly.

III. We have communicated with our Missionary at Fort McPherson regarding local labour and rough logs and have every confidence that the situation there will develop satisfactorily because many of the most intelligent people are anxious to have a school established.

IV. We have engaged Miss Catherine Herschel who has a First Class Teacher's Certificate for the Province of Ontario. Miss Herschel will go down by the first boat.
V. We are in touch with a firm about the desks for the children, etc., and have the assurance that these can be obtained in time, also blackboards, etc.

VI. We are having trouble about oil heaters and have only been able to secure two so far. I am wondering if we could secure a number of oil heaters from the Government from the Can Oil Project down the Mackenzie. Last summer in going down by air I was informed that there were some fifty oil heaters at the Can Oil Project. From Aklavik I wrote to Mr. McKinnon, Manager of the Imperial Oil Refinery at the Oil Wells asking his assistance in order to secure three of these oil heaters for me. Mr. McKinnon was South at the time and my letter was passed on to someone else who wrote advising me that these oil heaters were not for sale and he ventured the explanation the Government had not decided on the sale price of these. This was not very encouraging in view of the fact that the Americans had left Can Oil a year before.

Would it not be possible for you to contact the proper authority in Ottawa and secure four or more of these. We would then be quite willing to take over the two new ones that we have ordered. The main thing is that we must have heaters for the school.

RE: FORT McPHERSON DAY SCHOOL

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of 24th October, the following is an extract from a letter from our Missionary, the Rev. A.S. Dewdney, under date 16th August which gives a comprehensive report of the building of the new School:

"You will be expecting news on the progress of the school, etc. Mr. Hayward arrived on the boat along with most of the materials. He started to work at once and has got ahead very quickly. We had no idea the building would go up so quickly. There was some difficulty in getting workers. Mr. Hayward preferred to have only two men and we realized that if they were going to stay at the Fort with their families all summer we would have to pay them well, so we offered a straight wage of a dollar an hour. I went after some of the better workers. Unfortunately some of them had other work to do; several others promised to work but failed to appear. We finally got Abraham Francis and Brian Francis. Neither speaks English very well and neither is very experienced with a lumber building. Mr. Hayward has grumbled a good deal about them, but really I think they have done very well and they have stuck to the job without missing a day, turning up every morning at 8.30. And, as I say, the work has gone ahead very fast. After five weeks the building is almost finished, except for painting and some of the interior finishing. At present we have Fred Flirt and William Edward working as well. I worked for part of two afternoons, but I had quite a bit of other work to do and my help did not seem necessary. As a matter of..."
fact Mr. Hayward was hard put to it to keep his two men occupied in the last week or two before the second boat brought the remainder of the supplies. All being well, we hope to open school on September 2nd. If the desks have not arrived we will improvise something for the time being.

The blueprints have been adhered to except for minor details. A trap door was made in the ceiling of the hall to permit access to the chimneys below the roof, and another in the floor to permit access to the foundations. The cupboard in one of the cloakrooms was changed into a closet for the indoor toilet and another smaller cupboard built in one of the cloakrooms to take the cleaning equipment. One other temporary change has been made. The partition between the two classrooms has been left out. This can be put in later if necessary. But the main criticism I would make of the plans is in the small size of the classrooms. Each classroom will accommodate only about fifteen children. It seems foolish to have two teachers for only thirty children. Miss Herschel is anxious to have a space at the back of the room which can be used for games and more informal types of work so it seemed sensible to leave out the partition. As a matter of fact there was not enough wallboard to build it in any case.

While filling in time till the second boat came Mr. Hayward had two small toilets (outdoor) made and a small storehouse for keeping storm windows, extra equipment, etc. Both toilets and storehouse are to my mind too small. We had some spare materials but Mr. Hayward is extremely economical and did not want to build them even as large as they are.

The school has been built on the northwest corner of the N.T. lot about thirty or forty feet from each boundary. The front door faces the village to the north; the classroom windows face the south to allow maximum light in the winter. Miss Herschel suggests that awnings be procured for the classroom windows instead of blinds. The arrangement of the windows for ventilation makes it difficult to use blinds, but there should be some means of protection from the direct sun in spring and summer. I think that outside awnings are a very good idea. Also, eavestroughing should be procured and sent in at the first opportunity as the water from the roof will quickly undermine the foundations. I am trying to get ditches dug this fall to drain the land as much as possible. The teacher's room has windows giving an uninterrupted view of the river. There is plenty of room left on the property for other buildings and for a playground when we can get the ground levelled and drained."
We enclose a snapshot of a group in front of the new building. This is the only picture of the School we have at present but we are asking Mr. Dewdney to supply us with a set of photos of the several elevations. It will of course take time to get these.

Yours very truly,

Honorary-Secretary.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Meikle

Re: Fort McPherson

I visited Fort McPherson Indian Day School on June 23rd and found it to be in charge of Miss Catherine M. Herschel who holds a first-class permanent teacher's certificate and has 18 years of teaching experience. She teaches Grades 1, 2 and 4, and there are 25 pupils enrolled, all of whom were present at the time of the visit. They were classified as follows:

|       | Boys | Girls |
|-------|------|-------|
|       | H.B. | White | H.B. | White |
| Beginners | 3    | 3     |      |       |
| Grades 1 | 3    | 1     | 3    | 1     |
| Grades 2 | 3    | 1     | 2    | 1     |
| Grades 4 | 3    | 1     |      |       |

I tested the children to obtain some idea of the progress they had been making. The reading was average, the writing fair, but the children appeared to be very interested in their school work. I had a meeting with all of the Indians at the settlement. They spoke very highly and with appreciation of the work which Miss Herschel has been doing. Personally, I gathered the impression that Miss Herschel's interests were not fully with her work. However, this may be an unfair judgment. She is soon to be married, and she has requested to continue her teaching post until the end of March, 1948, when her husband will be returning from his trapping line in the Yukon.

The school receives radio broadcasts from Edmonton and Watrous. There is no film projector available. The children receive a medical examination at the beginning of each school year and some have been X-rayed for T.B. One of the local residents has donated to the school a small organ, and it is a great asset. While at the school I listened to some very fine singing by the children. The High Roads to Reading series of readers is used in this school. I am of the opinion that more satisfactory results would be obtained with basic readers, and would suggest that the school be furnished with same.

I noticed that there were no fire extinguishers in this school, and would suggest that the same be furnished as soon as possible, since there is considerable danger of fire due to the fact that gasoline lamps are used. The children have been placing the fuel oil in the burner, with the result that the floor about the stove is being ruined. This chore should be attended to by an adult. I noticed that there
were four window ventilators which are useless because there are no hinges attached thereto, so I would suggest that hinges be procured and installed on same. There are a considerable number of cracks in the floor as the result of shifting in the foundation caused by frost pressure. This item should also receive attention.

J. W. McKinnon.

Re your telegram of 8th instant concerning application of Joan Adams, Protestant school teacher. This matter was taken up with Canon L.G. Chappell, local Anglican minister. Excepting Old Crow, it was thought that Teslin warranted a day school more than any other place in the Yukon.

At this point there is a Roman Catholic and a Church of England seasonal school, both school rooms being in fairly good condition. There is an unoccupied Anglican teacheage in good condition. At this date there are very few Indian school-age children in the village - possibly four or five. Most of the children are out on trap-lines with their parents. It is thought that possibly a dozen children would remain behind with relatives if a day school were to be conducted.

There are, however, some 13 or 14 white and half-breed children without any school facilities whatever. I am informed that a petition was forwarded to the Territorial Government requesting a school at Teslin. In view of the situation at Teslin, I sent the following telegram to Archbishop W.R. Dear Archbishop Adams:

I have for answer your letter of January 5 concerning Miss Adams. If Miss Adams still wishes to go into the Yukon next September, I would advise that you consider her for the position of teacher at the Fort McPherson Indian Day School. We have just been advised by our Indian Superintendent at Fort Norman that Mrs. Miller, the teacher at McPherson, is resigning at Easter. As this school has been a great success, Mr. Hunter has suggested that every effort be made to replace Mrs. Miller.

The other teacher whom we have in mind for this school is Mr. Evans who formerly taught near Moose Factory, James Bay. He has just accepted a position at Chassawin, in northern Manitoba. I wrote recently to the Bishop of Brandon and asked if we could be definitely informed as to whether Mr. Evans still wishes to go into the Yukon as he originally requested. I will write you further when I hear definitely about Mr. Evans' plans. He has a Bachelor of Education degree from the University of Alberta and is particularly anxious to teach in the Yukon or Northwest Territories. He was sent to Chassawin because of the urgent need there for an Anglican teacher to finish out the winter.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,

Fort McPherson Indian Day School.

Dear Archdeacon Marsh:

Last summer we had some correspondence with Mr. Foster with regard to obtaining the services of another teacher for the above Indian Day School. At that time the teacher, Miss Catherine Herschel, was intending to get married and resign her position. However, we persuaded her to stay on as teacher after she was married.

We have now been advised by our Indian Superintendent at Fort Norman that she is resigning as of March 31, 1948.

We have been corresponding with Archbishop Adams with regard to the above school, due to a misunderstanding on our part that he was responsible for it. We have now been advised that we should correspond with your office concerning a replacement teacher.

The only teacher we have in mind who is willing to go in to the north is Miss Joan E. Adams of Kelowna, B.C. Miss Adams is 31 years of age and has five years' teaching experience in the B.C. Provincial Schools. She is a graduate of the University of British Columbia and holds a permanent high school teacher's certificate. She is particularly anxious to go into the north country and therefore we wrote to Archbishop Adams and requested that he interview her. Unfortunately, she is now teaching at a B.C. provincial school and will not be available until next summer. Therefore, we are faced with two alternatives with regard to this school -

(a) to have it closed from April 1 until June 30, 1948, and to then employ the services of Miss Adams or some other teacher as from 1 September, 1948,
(b) that we now try to obtain the services of a teacher from April 1 to June 30, 1948.

I would appreciate your comments on the situation at this school and would suggest that you write Archbishop Adams if you wish any further references with regard to Miss Adams.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Fort Norman, N.W.T.,
March 11, 1948.

I wish to state that I have recently returned from a visit of every settlement in this Indian Agency, at which time I visited all schools, spending as much time as possible with the teachers.

On February 26th, I visited the McPherson Indian Day School, with Mrs. K. Miller in charge. In my opinion this could be classed as a model Indian Day School for this country, as far as attendance is concerned. The natives of this Settlement appear to do everything in their power to assure the attendance of their children. This can be accounted for in two different ways. Firstly, the financial circumstances of the native of this district are better than average, secondly the Loucheux is considered the most intelligent type of Indian in the N.W.T.

In regard to the McPherson school, I have two suggestions to make for your consideration. The first is that a male teacher be obtained if possible, as it is believed he would be more capable of teaching handicraft and guiding in Welfare work. The second is that arrangements be made whereas the school term could start at June 1st, and continue until March 31st, the remaining time to be classed as holiday. This suggestion regarding the school term applies to all Indian Day schools in this part of the territory. During the months of April and May it is practically impossible to have the children attend school, this being the time when the Indians move with their families to the bush to take part in what is known as the Spring hunt. The results of this hunt could be classed as approximately seventy-five percent of the natives' yearly income, therefore this too, is an essential part of the children's education.

L C Hunter
Indian Agent

I have your application for employment in one of our day schools.

We have a vacancy at Fort McPherson, Northwest Territories which might interest you. This school was erected three years ago and the Indians in the vicinity have been doing quite well under the former teacher. This teacher has now left our service due to the fact she is now married. It is noted from your application that you hold an Elementary Intermediate teaching Certificate, and have had four years teaching experience. On our revised salary schedule, this would entitle you to a salary of $168.00 a teaching month. For a school in the Northwest Territories you can also make application for the Northern living allowance of $100.00 a teaching month. It is necessary to provide such an extra allowance because of the very high cost of living.

If you are interested in this school at Fort McPherson, I would be pleased to hear from you and will gladly furnish further details.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Margaret H. Skjeie,
Strathmore, Alberta.

Dear Miss Skjeie:

I have for answer your letter of June 1, 1948, with regard to the Fort McPherson Indian Day School. We have already appointed a teacher to this school since I last wrote you.

Would you be interested in a school at Masset, Queen Charlotte Islands, British Columbia. This is a two-room school and we will have a vacancy for a junior teacher there. If you would like any further details, I would ask you to write to Major R. F. Davey, District Inspector of Indian Schools, Federal Building, Vancouver, B. C.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

My Lord:

You called me by telephone on Monday and read me the following wire you had received from Archdeacon Marsh at Aklavik:

"Between church and old mission definite fire hazard to all property STOP Graveyard is end of Lot 5 STOP Survey shows road allowance between this lot and Lot 3 STOP Suggest apply for allowance in return for part of Lot 3 which government record shows as on our land and which with Lot 4 has native houses on it STOP School is on Lot 2 STOP Quick reply desired."

It appears that the message from Archdeacon Marsh has reference to the Indian day school at Fort McPherson, N.W.T., and was prompted by our letter dated May 17th last addressed to Mr. H. L. Alcorn, Honorary Secretary, Diocese of the Arctic, copy of which is attached. The object of this letter was to ascertain whether additional land could be obtained as a playground and school gardens for the school in question.

There seem to be two matters requiring attention. The first is the site of the school. We understand that, when the Indian Affairs Branch paid the cost of the erection of the school, the Branch did not insist upon getting title for the site because it was understood you were to obtain title from the Hudson's Bay Company, the owner of Lot 2. The matter of the title has not been stressed because you had made the arrangement and the Indian Affairs Branch was awaiting your return to health so that this item could be settled in accordance with the understanding the Branch had with you. I believe that they will now correspond with you about the title.

Right Reverend A.L. Fleming, D.D.,
Bishop of the Arctic,
The Church House, 604 Jarvis Street,
Toronto, Ontario.
The second point is the grounds for recreation for the school children, and what we wanted to know was whether there was land available for this purpose. Our School Inspector seems to think that there should be about three acres to be used for recreational facilities and school gardens. You will know whether any part of the land which stands in the name of the Anglican Mission can be made available. A plan of the Fort McPherson settlement is enclosed.

With kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

R.A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.
Copy for the information of Mr. Hoey

Dear Sir:

Dear Colonel Neary:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated 7th instant File No. 135-2-1 (E.1) re the site on which the Fort McPherson Day School is situated.

First, let me say that in reply to your letter dated 3rd February my Honorary-Secretary wrote to you on 17th February, 1947, stating that we would be glad to contribute the use of the land for the purpose intended but that we had no desire to ask for any payment or to transfer it to the Government.

The land was donated to us by the Hudson's Bay Company for the purpose of erecting a day school thereon. At that time the Government did not see its way to establish a school on its own responsibility and therefore it was necessary for us to take the initiative. Very soon, however, the Department of Indian Affairs agreed to pay for the cost of the school, etc., provided we assume all responsibility in connection with the same.

My Archdeacon is at Fort McPherson at the moment and will return in September. Perhaps then you would be kind enough to take the matter up with me.

With all kind wishes,

Yours sincerely,

A. L. Fleming
Bishop of The Arctic.

While it is true that the numbers actually attending the day school is oftentimes very small, it must be remembered that the school is kept open every day for all in the vicinity and that help is given to the children who are living at a distance by providing them with school material which is made use of by other members of the family who have passed through the school either at Macpherson or at the Hay River Boarding School. As a result of the above there is more English spoken at Macpherson than at any other point along the Mackenzie River.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of March 25th regarding the Fort McPherson School, I beg to say that no payment has been made pending receipt of a report which you intimated you would forward following the treaty paying trip.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of August 30th, file 13542-2, in connection with Fort McPherson School.

This school has been kept open for various periods during the last few years to my certain knowledge, and at various times I have sent quarterly returns signed by myself to the Department.

On visiting McPherson this Summer I found that the school had been kept open from New Year's until the end of June and I have already forwarded to the Department the quarterly return for the Fort McPherson School for the quarter ending March 31, 1935, and the record for that quarter seems to be a very good one.

I believe the present Incumbent of the position as Church of England Missionary at Fort McPherson is a sincere, capable teacher, and very earnest to make the school a successful and profitable one for the Indian children. As his wife a graduate of Toronto University in medicine of 1935 is now with him I am sure we can expect a very successful school to be maintained there. Therefore, I would recommend that a salary of $25.00 per month be allowed Reverend T. Greenwood for each month on which the school is kept open. This, of course, to be dependent on the number of children attending regularly.

The children attending this school are all recognized as Treaty Indian children.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

It was, therefore, presumed that the school had been closed and no provision was made for the salary of a teacher at this point in our Appropriation for the current fiscal year.

A recent letter from Dr. W.A.M. Truesdell, Indian Agent at Fort Simpson, N.W.T., points out that the present Church of England missionary at Fort McPherson is a very capable teacher and that he has reopened the Fort McPherson Day School and has been conducting it since January 1st of this year. Returns have been forwarded for the period January 1st to June 30th, last.

Dr. Truesdell recommends salary at the rate of $25 a month for the period the school is open. I would appreciate your concurrence in making this allowance.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I returned from the Eastern Arctic this week and am trying to pick up the various matters that have to be dealt with before I leave for the West next week.

My Honorary-Secretary has drawn my attention to the fact that we have an accumulation of bills in connection with the Fort McPherson Day School amounting to between seven and eight thousand dollars that have been forwarded to you for payment but as far as we know no payment has been made. For example, the T. Eaton Co. Ltd., Edmonton have written and they have kindly agreed to hold the matter until 1st September by which date they expect to hear from you.

I know full well that owing to the holiday season reducing the staff, etc., it must be difficult for your department to keep up-to-date regarding accounts rendered, etc. On the other hand I do think that some attention should be paid to this matter and I would be very grateful to you if you would be so kind as to take such action as will cause these accounts to be paid.

Trusting this will find you in good health and with kindest personal regards,

WISH TO ADVISE MR DEWDNEY HAS TAKEN ALL LUMBER NAILS BUILDING PAPER ROOFING AND PAINT FROM THE SCHOOL TO THE POSSIBLE VALUE OF AT LEAST FOUR HUNDRED DOLLARS STOP HE FIRST STATED THAT THE ARCTIC DIOCESE OFFICE GAVE HIM PERMISSION TO TAKE LUMBER NOW HE CLAIMS ALL BUILDING MATERIAL IS TIMELY CORRECT= HERSCHELL TEACHER INDIAN DAY SCHOOL
Ottawa, May 6th, 1947.

Dear Mr. Foster:

Re: Fort McPherson Day School

We have just received the following telegram dated May 5th, from Miss Herschell, teacher of the Fort McPherson School:

"WISH TO ADVISE MR. DEWDNEY HAS TAKEN ALL LUMBER NAILS BUILDING PAPER ROOFING AND PAINT FROM THE SCHOOL TO THE POSSIBLE VALUE OF AT LEAST FOUR HUNDRED DOLLARS STOP HE FIRST STATED THAT THE ARCTIC DIOCESE OFFICE GAVE HIM PERMISSION TO TAKE LUMBER NOW HE CLAIMS ALL BUILDING MATERIAL IS THIS CORRECT"

If the material to which Miss Herschell refers was left over following the construction of the school last year, it is presumed that this department paid for it and consequently, Reverend Mr. Dewdney would have no right to remove it.

On the other hand, the material may belong to the Diocese of the Arctic and was just stored in the school, in which case, of course, we would have nothing to say about its disposition.

I would appreciate it if you would enlighten me on the above situation.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Referring to your letter of 6th instant. There was a small amount of lumber left over but I had not understood it to be of anything like the value put upon it by Miss Herschel. How she arrives at such a sum one can only guess. Unfortunately there is a marked lack of good feeling between her and our missionary and while, of course, we would not attribute her report to malice, but rather to her feeling of duty as a Government employee, she would not tend to understate the case.

The Bishop and I discussed, during the building operations, of asking for an amount to compensate the Diocese for the services rendered in the way of oversight and financing from the planning stage to completion of the building and its furnishing. This to include local supervision by our Missionary. On consideration, however, it was decided not to do so but when, later on, it developed there was a small amount of lumber left over we wrote November 20th to Mr. Dewdney as follows, "I think we need not press the matter of your work and supervision on the Government. What would you think of taking over the surplus lumber as an offset to that and to the services of the Diocese in financing?". He does not seem to have answered this query but to have taken it as authority to use the lumber. Later on we learned that there were two kegs of nails left over and, as we were in need of all the nails we could get for the new day school we are building this summer at Tuktoyaktuk, we instructed our Missionary to ship them to that point. We have no information regarding possible surplus of roofing, building paper and paint.

We are sending a copy of this letter to the Rev. A.S. Dewdney so that he can inform us, as far as he can judge, what would be the value of the surplus material. When I have received this information I shall be glad to account to you for the amount involved.

Yours truly,

Honorary-Treasurer.

Dear Mr. Foster:

Your letter of May 7th arrived last night, and I hasten to answer.

If you will look over our correspondence further you will see that I did answer the point raised re lumber left over from the school. I quote from my reply dated December 11th, "I would suggest that it would be very handy if we should take over the balance of lumber and other supplies in lieu of any claim for the work and worry of the office or myself. Lumber can always be used. Incidentally I wrote the Bishop that I had already used some of the lumber to make us benches for the Indian Room. All our chairs had to be lent to the school when the desks did not arrive. But there is still a useful amount left".

In reply to this you wrote in your letter of January 6th, "It had also occurred to me that we should take over the surplus of the lumber and other supplies as an offset to any claim that we might have for your work and supervision and certainly no amount of material so left over could compensate this office for the annoyance and trouble handling the matter so I think we will just let the matter rest unless, of course, the Government should ask us about it. Incidentally I am satisfied that the building cost the Government very much less than if they had undertaken the work themselves but, of course, we need not look to any thanks for that".

I took it from this reply that we would take over the lumber and other surplus supplies, and let the matter rest there as far as compensation to ourselves was concerned.

I told Miss Herschel, probably some time in March that we were taking over the lumber left from the school building, using the term "lumber" in a general sense and without any intention of distinguishing it from paint, tar paper, etc. I mentioned it to her again later on, and neither time did she question my right to do so. She had ample time to wire or write out about the matter, or to consult Dr. Harvey on his visit here before I took the lumber etc., over.
Only one incident occurred as we were ready to leave the school. She came out and saw the paint loaded on the tractor, and asked me if I was taking that, as she was supposed to get the outside of the school painted this summer. I replied that I had been told by the office that we were taking over all materials left over from the building of the school. There was only "inside" paint left. I added that she might remember that we had lent the school a large amount of Mission paint in order that the work might not be delayed, and it had not yet been returned. She replied, "Yes, I know that". This is the sum total of any conversation I have had with her on this matter, and I had no idea that any such question had been raised until your letter yesterday.

I have mentioned already that the paint was ours without any question by reason of our loan to the school. In addition, we supplied two sheets of tentest or donnecona board from our supply here, when the school supply ran out. This has not been replaced. In addition to the hours I spent checking freight, sorting it, hiring the men, and all the rest of it, the school is under an obligation to us for being able to run at all this winter. No desks had arrived, as the boat bringing them was frozen in at Aklavik (they finally arrived today). We supplied the school with a large collapsible table belonging to the W.A., with three smaller tables from the Mission house, and twenty-five chairs, most of them almost new. Many of these are now in bad shape, with rungs broken, and the table is very wobbly. (This was a specially made table with heavy removable plywood top, about 5' x 10', used by the women to sew and cut out, and by us to sort the mail - we have been badly handicapped by the lack of it all winter). In addition, we turned over to them what school materials we had around. I wrote last fall what a ludicrously small supply of materials was sent in. We borrowed Readers from the school at Aklavik. In addition, we turned over to Miss Herschel thirty or forty books of our own, or rather Michael's, most of them children's classics in good condition.

My own personal reaction is one of some resentment. The Government departments are forgetting the immense debt they owe the Missions for all the educational work carried on by our Missionaries here and elsewhere for many years past with no remuneration whatever. I have been handling the rations for the I.D. for ten years, and other men before me. Mrs. Dewdney handles all the vital statistics here, and carried on the medical work for seven years without remuneration, as well as the first year's work of organizing the Family Allowance. We often have to handle matters that are really the concern of the Police, because there is no Policeman stationed here, and no one else willing to accept responsibility. I do not see why we should continue to do so.

One further note about the disposal of this lumber and other supplies. How Miss Herschel made her guesstimate of their value, I do not know, but I think it is exaggerated. I have used, in finishing the interior of the Church approximately the following:-

Dear Sir:

We thank you for your letter of June 3rd with reference to shipment of Movable Chair Desks to Fort McPherson, N.W.T., via Waterways transportation.

Last fall when these desks missed the boat, the Secretary of the Diocese of the Arctic in Toronto called us and wanted to know what to do about it. The Railway Company also called us and said they could either store them or return them. After several phone calls, our Western representative decided to accept these and resold them. This part shipment missing the boat was due to circumstances beyond our control. We did not have the lumber to complete this order and had to make up the desks after receipt of the order, and whatever shipment we did make to this School previously we had in stock.

We cannot see why we should have to supply these desks this year again, at last year's prices. As you know, all material and labor costs have gone up. Even if the desks were kept out there and stored it would have cost you quite a bit more than the difference in the increase in price.

We trust that you will be able to take care of the invoice at the current prices.

Sincerely yours,

Sales Department.

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. McKinnon:

I thought you would like to know that the R.C.A. Victor record playing instrument has arrived in good condition. I am contacting the RCCS at Aklavik to ask them to install it for us.

After my first night here I wrote to Mr. Hunter about the contraption which serves as a bed, but so far I have not heard from him about this. It may be that he will deal with the matter when he come to Fort McPherson next month. But in case he does not, I feel that I must tell you that I have not had a proper night's sleep on it ever since I came here. It is composed of two strips, which in the day time form the seat and back of a settee. At night, when they are in position for sleeping, there is a gap between these two strips, were the spring or the seat portion and the spring of the back portion are supposed to meet. In any case the seat strip is higher than the other one, and curves upwards. As there is no real mattress, but just springs with a small amount or padding, the draughts from the floor come up through the "bed". But one of the worst things is that it is impossible to tuck in the bed clothes, as the "thing" is in one piece and there is nothing to tuck them under.

At present I am recovering from a chill, and I feel that it was caused by the bed clothes slipping off and leaving me without cover.

What can be done about it?

I am sorry to trouble you with this, but I don't want to be ill and it would be lunacy to sleep on this during the winter.

Yours very truly,

'sgd' E. M. Hinds.

OTTAWA, October 12, 1948.

Col. B. F. Neary, Superintendent of Education, Indian Affairs Branch, Capital Theatre Building, 220 Queen St., Ottawa.

Re: Fort McPherson Indian Day School

Last week Superintendent Martin of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police phoned this office and said that he had just completed a tour of inspection in the Northwest Territories. During his visit in the north country he called on Miss Hinds, Principal of the Fort McPherson Day School. He said that an ice house, storage space for rations and better living quarters were needed at this school. At present the teacher gets her ice from the local Royal Canadian Mounted Police Detachment, which according to Superintendent Martin is most unsatisfactory. He thought that living quarters in the Port Braeant day school were superior to those at Fort McPherson. As both schools are almost identical -- it would be an easy matter to make the living accommodation at Fort McPherson similar to that at Port Braeant.

J. W. MacKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

Extract from a letter from Miss E. M. Hinds teacher in the Indian Day School at Fort McPherson, N.W.T. under date of November 30, 1948.

Another serious problem here is that many Indians do not use toilets. I wonder whether a few groups of public toilets might help to solve the problem. I am doing all I possible can to deal with the matter through education, but I expect it would take a hundred years to effect all that is desirable. Without enforcement by the Police I think little can be accomplished and Police are here so seldom that little can be done about enforcement.

The fact that many use the bushes near the river is one of the worst aspects, for in spring the river floods and those with no ice houses have to drink the flood water. That means me too at present though I hope that an ice house which has been offered to the school for $100.00 will be purchased before the spring floods.
Fort McPherson Indian Day School

J. W. J.

Dear Mr. McKinnon,

Thank you for your letters of 24th and 26th June, and for the Phonograph Needle.

I am delighted to know that one RCA Victor Record Player has been sent to the school, and also that chemistry equipment is on its way.

I have been talking to Mr. Gilley about a school garden and have already made a small beginning, but we have no tools and I enclose a list of requirements.

I am also sending a copy to Mr. Hunter.

The harmonium in the school belongs to Sara Linnan and she wants it back. She has had no payment for the loan of it and she says that Mrs. Miller promised payment.

Mrs. Dewdney wants to sell her piano for $300. It is a big old fashion, shabby instrument and not worth $300, in my estimation, but it would be useful in the school as the tone is not...
for the girls. My own sewing machine is in my baggage, which is coming by boat.

The idea at the back of my mind is to encourage, by this means, a desire to make their homes clean, new, and attractive. The sewing they do at home is all of one kind.

I am glad some paint boxes arrived. It would be nice to have some large tubes of water colour paint, especially of the primary colours, to use for refilling boxes as colours get used up. These are preferable to refill pans of paint, as they can be used with saucers for palettes when co-operative efforts at painting scenery for plays are undertaken, though powder colours are perhaps better for this purpose.

With kind regards,

Yours very truly,
E. M. Harris.

I refer to your letter of September 20, 1948, with copy of a letter written by Miss Hinds, teacher of Fort McPherson Indian Day School to the Inspector of schools Mr. J.W. McKinnon, attached. As you have requested my recommendations regarding the equipment as asked for by Miss Hinds, I will deal with each article separately.

The piano referred to by Miss Hinds is the property of Mrs. A.S. Dewdney, wife of the Anglican church Minister who was stationed at McPherson until the past year. I am of the opinion that the piano would be an asset to the McPherson school, but believe that the price of $300.00 is far in excess of the value of the instrument. It is considered that a fair price for this piano would be $150.00. If you are of the opinion that this piano would be useful at McPherson school, Mrs. Dewdney could be contacted at Coleman, Alberta, and an offer of $150.00 made to her for the instrument, which I imagine she would accept, as the cost of moving the instrument to some other point would be exorbitant.

It will be noted that on the estimates for the fiscal year 1948/50 that the cost of erecting an icehouse has been included. It may be possible to purchase a small building in the Settlement to be used for the purpose of ice storage and as I expect to be in McPherson after the freeze-up period, I will check on this matter and report to your office. I may mention that before any buildings are moved onto or erected on the school property that the matter of title to the property be settled, in this regard I refer to my letter, file C-31, dated Oct. 5th, 1948.

- to page two -
Regarding the handicraft material as requested by Miss Hinds, I believe that the knitting needles, wool, and cotton material could be purchased locally and if you are of the opinion that these articles should be supplied I will attempt to obtain a small quantity from the local Hudson's Bay Trading Post. Regarding the wood working equipment as mentioned by Miss Hinds, it is impossible to purchase such articles locally but as a quantity of such equipment was supplied to the C.E. residential school at Aklavik, I may possibly be able to obtain one of each article from that school and have it transferred to McPherson, in this way we could requisition for these articles to McPherson School in the coming year and replace the borrowed articles to Aklavik school. As I stated previously, I will be at McPherson and Aklavik sometime in November or December and will see if such arrangements will be possible.

I note from Miss Hinds' letter that a list of garden tools required is attached. I may state that I was of the opinion that it was the responsibility of the Welfare Division of the Indian Affairs branch to supply such tools and therefore in submitting the annual estimates I included garden tools for McPherson settlement. It may be mentioned that these tools will not arrive at McPherson in time for early gardening, but it is believed that arrangements can be made to borrow tools for the planting of a garden and the tools ordered should arrive sometime in July. I may further mention that garden seeds have been ordered through the Welfare Division and that these were for the purpose of having Miss Hinds give the children and adults some instruction in this regard.

Miss Hinds appears to be taking a very keen interest in assisting the natives. The former teacher at this point was unable to undertake any work of this kind, I was therefore not prepared when submitting the requisitions for this school, of the handicraft material etc., that would be required, however I feel that some of this material could be obtained locally and would ask that I be advised if purchase should be made.

Copy, Miss Hinds letter attached.

L.G. Hunter,
Superintendent,
Ft. Norman Agency.

We have just received your letter of October 10th and have given careful consideration to the second paragraph regarding the purchase of a piano.

It has not been our practice to supply a piano at a one room school for reasons that will readily suggest themselves to you. However, we are aware that in some of our one room schools there is a piano but it has been purchased either by the Indians or as a result of the teacher and the Indians combining and holding some kind of entertainment and raising the necessary funds.

It is noted that we will hear further from you regarding the cost of erecting an ice house. You may purchase a small quantity of handicraft material from the local Hudson's Bay trading post.

Col. B.F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Fort McPherson Indian Day School

This will acknowledge your letter January 24th, 1949, regarding the living quarters of the Fort McPherson Indian Day School. Recently I visited Fort McPherson taking with me the plans of the Fort Brabant Day School. A comparison was made and little difference could be found between these two buildings other than Fort Brabant School having a cupboard in one corner of the teacher's room.

In my opinion the living quarters for a Welfare teacher at Fort McPherson are inadequate. It must be realized the teacher now at Fort McPherson is doing welfare work and this must be carried on within her one small room. As it is at the present time the furnishings in this room consist of a kitchen range, a bed, desk, studio lounge and chair. All this being confined within a space eleven feet by sixteen feet. It is very seldom that Miss Hinds has less than three or four Indians visiting her for welfare reasons.

At the present time there are absolutely no facilities for the teacher to bathe and make her toilet. In viewing the plans of the present school I am of the opinion that rooms of a comfortable size could be added at a minimum cost. In this connection I left the plans that your forwarded to me with Miss Hinds and a Mr. Fred Firth of McPherson with the request that Mr. Firth, who is a carpenter, submit a list of materials necessary for such an addition.

Upon receiving the list of materials as required for this work I will submit same to your office.
for your consideration, and possible check and approval by the department engineers. This will be submitted as soon as possible so that the work, if approved, may be done during the summer vacation.

I am definitely of the opinion that these improvements are imperative. On annual estimates this year I stated that it would be necessary to build a warehouse at this point. Should an addition be made to the teacher's quarters this would not be necessary.

L. C. Hunter,
Superintendent.
March 21, 1949.

AIR MAIL

Mr. L.G. Hunter,

Fort Mohrson Indian Day School
Ref. your 6-31 (142) of March 4

We agree with your recommendation that the living quarters at this school be enlarged during the coming summer. I note that you are of the opinion that rooms of comfortable size could be added quite easily. I am pleased that you have located a carpenter in Fort Mohrson who will forward a list of materials required for this work. I presume that you will also recommend that Mr. Firth be employed as a foreman carpenter for these alterations. I also note that it will not be necessary to build a warehouse at this point if the addition to the teacher's quarters is made.

As soon as the bill of materials is received here and approved by our officials, we will send it to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for purchase orders. Therefore, you should include in your requisition complete shipping instructions.

Bernard F. Henry
Superintendent of Education.

Further to your letter of January 24, 1949, and to my correspondence dated March 4, 1949, regarding the remodeling of the teachers quarters at Ft. McPherson, N.W.T.

Mr. Johnston of the Department of Public Works was passing through Ft. Norman, N.W.T. recently, and his opinion was asked regarding the plans as submitted by Miss Hinds for the remodeling of the teacher's quarters at Ft. McPherson. Mr. Johnston had visited the Settlement of Ft. McPherson a few days previously to our conversation and was aware of the type of building at Ft. McPherson. On viewing the sketch as submitted by Miss Hinds, Mr. Johnston suggested that I allow him to take the original blue print of the school and the sketch, stating that he would have a draughtsman make a regular blue print out of the sketch and also submit an estimate of the cost that it would take to have the material supplied and the addition to the building erected.

I may mention that the Department of Public Works are going to have a crew of carpenters at McPherson this coming summer to erect a building for the Forestry and Wildlife Service. It is my opinion that it would be an advantage to our Branch to have any work that we require at McPherson done while this construction crew are at that point.

As Mr. Johnston is submitting direct to your office, the original blue print of the school, the blue print of the suggested addition to the teacher's quarters, also an estimate of the cost, I would appreciate being informed of your opinion in this regard.

L.C. Hunter,
Superintendent.

Re; Supplying of Electric Power,
Ft. McPherson Indian Day School.

As you are aware the above school has been supplied by light from Gasoline and Kerosene lamps during the past years. On a recent visit to this school it was noted where a serious fire was averted due only to the quick action on the part of the teacher, when these gasoline lamps suddenly burst into flames.

This past summer, the Department of National Health & Welfare, Indian Health Services, erected a Nursing station at the settlement of Fort McPherson and installed a 3 K.V., 110 Volt A.C. Lighting Plant. As there is a surplus of power at the Nursing station, I took the matter up with Dr. Proctor of Indian Health Services regarding supplying of Power to our Indian Day school. Dr. Proctor was of the opinion that this could be arranged.

In this regard, I have attached a requisition covering all the requirements for having Electric power installed in our school. You will note that I have asked that fluorescent lights be supplied for the classrooms. It may be pointed out that during the winter months at McPherson, artificial light is necessary for the entire school day, therefore I hope that the requisition as submitted will meet with your approval.

With regard to the installation of these fixtures, we can no doubt make arrangements with Indian Health Services Branch, to obtain the services of an employee of theirs a Mr. M.F. Hall, who is an electrician.

I was recently in the Northwest Territories and, while there, met Mr. L. C. Hunter, Superintendent of Indian Agencies, who discussed the situation regarding the public school at Fort McPherson, N.W.T. Mr. Hunter stated that he had received an urgent request for enlargement of the teacher's quarters at this school and had sketches prepared of what was required. He handed me a blueprint of this school, and I offered to have a preliminary plan prepared incorporating the enlargement which was proposed.

This enlargement - 12' x 28' - has been included on a plan which is now being sent you. The new addition would provide two rooms as living quarters for the teacher, and leave the room in the existing building as a public office and a place where the teacher could meet the public.

My offer to have these sketches prepared was due to the infrequent mail service in the Lower MacKenzie area and also the fact that, if anything were to be accomplished in this school enlargement, prompt action would have to be taken by the Department of Education at Ottawa.

Under the Committee for Northern development, the Department of Public Works has been designated as the construction agency for Fort McPherson, and will this year have a carpenter crew at that place to construct a warden's cabin and auxiliary buildings for the Lands and Development Services branch of the Department of Mines and Resources. Thus, if it is decided to build this addition to the school, the carpenter crew when there could do so. The materials, however, must leave Waterways early in May in order to go on the first barges which are due to arrive at Fort McPherson on or about July 5th. If any materials do not arrive by the first barges, there is practically no hope of carrying out construction this year.

No Estimate of cost has been made for this proposed enlargement as I did not feel like taking the time to do so, if the scheme itself were not approved. However,

Please send one bedstead and interior spring mattress.

Simmons Slumber King bed with Simmons Invincible spring-filled mattress size 3 ft or 3'6" wide are very suitable. Bed is the only kind of comfort or relaxation to be had here, so I hope that something really comfortable will be sent here.

In my opinion a bed is better than a divan for a welfare teacher because:

I. A bed is higher above floor level. I recently took the temperature in several places in the teacher's room with the following results:
- On floor under bed 32 degrees
- On top of bed 50 degrees
- On pillow 51 degrees
- On shelf over the side of the bed and about five feet above floor level 64 degrees.

All these readings were taken during one hour.

II. Numerous natives come into my room to tell me their troubles - real or imaginary - and I feel that it would be difficult to keep them off a divan since it is obviously made to be sat on. They would not sit on a bed.

Of course a bed in the room gives it the appearance of an Indian's cabin, especially as there is a cook stove there too, but I think that the comfort of the teacher is of greater importance than the appearance of the room, the circumstances being what they are.

The west end of the building could well be made into proper living quarters for the teacher by adding rooms to that end of the building. Those who visit the new nursing station and then come to call on me usually make such a remark as this, "Is this all you've got to live in? Good God!"

Rooms added to the end of the building could include:
- Bathroom, toilet, bedroom, living room, kitchen.

At present the toilet is in the most public place in the building. At present the boys' cloakroom is being used, as it was in Mrs. Miller's time, as a kitchen and oil-can room etc. It is needed for its proper purpose. The cupboard where I keep my food etc., and that used as a toilet are both needed for storing school materials. For instance, I keep the Victrola and the projector, records, etc. in my room for safety.

When sending furniture etc. to the new school I hope that care will be taken to get harmonious colour arrangement and to have curtains that catch the light, not curtains with a grey background. I would suggest that window panes be fitted inside rather than outside. In cleaning them there is a certain amount of pressure on the glass plate, and the strong sunlight in summer helps weaken the putty so that in winter there are drafts coming in round the edges of almost every pane. The inside arrangement would make re-plugging a simple job that could be done as required, provided a supply of putty were on hand.

Dear Colonel Neary,

I enclose a copy of the requisition which I submitted to Mr. Hunter. You will notice that the requisition which Mr. Hunter submitted is not identical with mine.

The items which I have marked with an asterisk, should, in my opinion, be sent to the school. I think it would be a good idea in future if requisitions for school supplies were submitted to an educationist in your department.

As your reply to my enquiry which was made last August did not reach me until February this year I was unable to do anything about purchasing the Dewdney's piano for the school, or to undertake school needlework with the girls as there were no materials.

I have given consideration to a number of questions that have been occupying my attention and I have decided to seek a post in an Eskimo community. Whether I shall find one or not is another
I am writing to Mr. R.A. Gibb about attendance at this school as he asked me to do. You will probably see the letter and you will notice that estimated attendance for next year is:

Treaty Indians 40
non-treaty 10 or more

All children here receive free books, pencils, and milk or cocoa at morning and afternoon recess.

I think it would be in the best interests of education for the living quarters and furnishing and equipment for cooking, etc. to be of the same standard as that which the nurse and her assistant enjoy at the nursing station.

Yours sincerely,

E.M. Hunter

Re: Fort McPherson Indian Day School

I refer to your wireless message of March 30, 1950, and to answer by A.V. Cottrell, Agency Assistant, also to my wire dated March 31, 1950, regarding additions to the above Indian Day School.

Loucheux Band No. 7, at Fort McPherson, N.W.T. according to our statistics, have 83 children between the ages of 7 and 16 years. Of this number there are 32 children attending the Aklavik Residential School, leaving a total of 51 pupils to attend day school at McPherson. These figures do not include children of 5 and 6 years of age who will attend school.

Loucheux Band No. 6, at Arctic Red River, N.W.T., according to our statistics, have 48 children between the age of 7 and 16 years. Of this number there are 32 attending the residential school at Aklavik, N.W.T. leaving a total of 18 children to attend day school.

As you are aware, the present plans include the building of a 2 room Indian Day school at Arctic Red River, this coming summer. This school is to be erected on the same plan as the ones at Ft. Norman and Ft. Good Hope. The matter of having the school divided to act as both Nursing Station and school has been taken up with the Director of Indian Health Services. The Director of Indian Health Services feels that the settlement of Arctic Red River is not large enough to warrant a permanent Nursing Station, therefore the suggestion to have the school divided to serve both school and nursing station has been rejected.

The Indian Day School that we now have at Fort McPherson was built to accommodate a maximum of 30 pupils, however this past year we managed to have an attendance of 36 pupils. It was necessary to also refuse admittance to a few pupils who would have liked to attend. Miss Stewart, our welfare teacher, in a recent report, states that with a hostel in operation we would have at least 70 pupils attending the McPherson Day School. Our statistics show that there were 22 births from June, 1948 to June 1949, in Loucheux Band 7. With an increase such as this our present school facilities are definitely inadequate.
My suggestion to remedy the situation that now exists, would be to move all the materials that are now on hand for the erection of a school at Arctic Red River, to Fort McPherson, N.W.T. and have the large two room day school erected at that point. The present small day school now in use at McPherson could be used as a hostel to accommodate the children while the parents are on the trap lines. That further material be shipped to Arctic Red River for a small one room day school with teacher's quarters.

I believe that if the two room school as planned for Arctic Red River was to be erected at Ft. McPherson, it would solve the schooling problem for many years to come. I further believe that if a small one room school with teacher's quarters combined, was to be erected at Arctic Red River, it would not be overcrowded for many years.

I am attaching herewith a copy of a letter recently received from Miss Stewart, our welfare teacher at McPherson, N.W.T., for your information.

L.C. Hunter,
Superintendent,
Fort Norman Indian Agency.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 27th in reference to Fort McPherson, N.W.T., and the several instructions I received from Col. B. F. Neary, Superintendent of Indian Education:

(a) Regarding the construction of a 12-foot addition to the school as planned for 1950-51, when the letter of authority giving the financial encumbrance is received, this work will be included in our programme for the present season.

(b) Regarding the transfer of surplus materials from Arctic Red River, N.W.T., where a one-classroom school is to be built, this material will be shipped to Fort McPherson during the present season. There are only two sailings of the boats in this area; freight leaves waterways June 3rd and August 5th and the barges would arrive in the Lower Mackenzie river area at Arctic Red River and McPherson about a month later. That would mean that the freight from Arctic Red River would be transferred to Fort McPherson about July 3rd or September 5th. In all probability our operations at Arctic Red River would be completed before September 5th, and every effort should be made for the transfer on or about July 3rd at Arctic Red River. Our plans here will be scheduled for the transfer on this date; that is, July 3rd approximately ex Arctic Red River.

(c) Regarding this item, "that an educational survey be made of this settlement to ascertain the number of classrooms and sizes required", it is indicated that a two-room school will be required at Fort McPherson and there has also been a suggestion from time to time that dormitory space is needed at that point. This, however, is a matter which will be covered in the educational survey to be made, as this Department (Public Works) is only the construction agency and is only concerned in carrying out instructions after a line of policy has been formulated and approved.

Fort McPherson is a settlement which is crowded, and on which the buildings now there do not wholly correspond to existing lots as per an original survey of some years ago. The settlement was visited by a Dominion Land Surveyor in 1949 and I understand some extensive changes were made in the existing surveyed lots, and also considerable areas of adjacent ground were also surveyed into lots. No doubt, once this enlarged survey of the settlement is approved, there will be numerous requests for lots on the new surveyed ground. At least this situation can be anticipated, as it is known to result elsewhere after a new survey has been made. The point of the matter is this:

(1) That whoever is looking into the educational needs of the settlement will need to act promptly so as to

(OVER)
have land reserved before other parties are making checkerboard reservations of lots which would spoil a school layout.

(2) That the grounds selected be sufficiently large for all educational needs of the settlement, both present and future. The area now reserved for school purposes is small with not much space for playgrounds. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have a lot adjacent to the school and it is possible those looking into the educational needs might consider an exchange of lots necessary so as to have all the school area within one compact block of land.

When goods are moved from Arctic Red River, these should be hauled directly to the school property and such as could be stored outside so taken care of and the materials requiring protection placed within temporary buildings. It is impossible to do this unless it is known where the grounds are approved for school purposes and also the exact location of the school buildings on these grounds. Any temporary warehouses are generally improved and allowed to remain as a permanent installation for storage purposes in connection with the school activities. For the above reasons, it is evident that considerable prompt attention will have to be given to this whole project so as to have instructions received here prior to July 3rd when the materials will have been transferred from Arctic Red River. Likewise, any materials which it is necessary to purchase should also be shipped from Waterways so as to reach Fort McPherson on the same barges by August 3rd. The second arrival of the barges about September 5th at Fort McPherson is too near freeze-up, and it might be impractical in some years to properly receive these goods and have them stored while the construction crew is at that place.

All indications appear to point to some additional accommodations being required for pupils and teachers at Fort McPherson, and the need appears to be quite urgent. The planning and delivery of materials can be done during 1950-51, with construction carried out in 1951-52. However, if there is any delay in receipt of instructions at this office, there might well be a delay in completion of the school at Fort McPherson.

J. E. Kellett,
Acting District Engineer.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

Arctic Red River Indian Day School

Fort McPherson Indian Day School

As a result of considerable correspondence over the past winter, it has been decided to make the following changes in our building program in the Mackenzie District:

(1) At Arctic Red River a one-room day school only will be erected in place of the two-room day school planned. A careful check of pupil population indicates that there are sufficient only for a one-room school at this point.

(2) All surplus materials now stored at Arctic Red River will be shipped to Fort McPherson, where it is planned to erect a two-room school. Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Teslin Lake Joint School

Reference is to your query regarding the salary of the teacher.

It appears that no action is necessary by this Department concerning the salary paid to this teacher (presently Miss Clancy) as she is a full-time employee of the Yukon Territorial school system.

You have seen the photographs of this school and my comments thereon, and you have approved the suggestion to defer construction at this point until the possible developments at Teslin appear more clearly.

This development may include the provision of facilities for children of the R.C.A.F. personnel. In that event the Yukon Government and the Department of National Defence might be influenced to set up a larger establishment suited to the needs of an enlarged white population. Provision for married quarters is already being made at the Watson Lake air station and Teslin is, I understand, next on the list for this enlargement.

In his letter of October 4, the Superintendent of Yukon schools outlines the agreement under which these joint schools are operated. Our Department is somewhat in
arrears in providing the school building. An associated Department is, however, providing accommodation for the teacher. Perhaps we should ask Mr. Superintendent Meek whether we are providing fuel for the school and the residence. Light for the school is supplied by the airport electricity plant.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

1. **SITE**: Please find attached a sketch just received from Mr. School Inspector McKinnon, in which he advises that the only suitable location for the new school is on the southeast corner of Lot 2; this is on the same lot where the present one-room school is located. The ground there is level and high and the new school should be located as close as possible to the southeast corner of Lot 2 so as to provide plenty of ground to the west for a playground.

2. **TEACHERAGE**: I have just received also an army message from the teacher, Miss Stewart, reading as follows:

   "MR. KELLETT THINKS THAT THE ALTERATION I ASKED FOR IS NOT POSSIBLE SO PLEASE DROP THE MATTER I DO NOT WANT ANY DELAY IN COMPLETION OF THE BUILDING."

3. **LIGHTING**: Would it be possible for Mr. Kellett to arrange for the school to be wired while his men are in Fort McPherson? Please return Mr. McKinnon's sketch in due course.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
