July 26, 1950.

R. BLAIS, CHIEF ENGINEER, DPW, OTTAWA,

In reply to your letter of July 24th concerning the rearrangement of the addition to the teacher's quarters at Fort McPherson, this matter was brought to my attention directly by Miss Stewart, the teacher at Fort McPherson, by radiogram on July 17th.

The alteration as suggested by Miss Stewart places the kitchen in the room now shown as the bedroom, with a doorway in each wall, and leaves no wall space whatsoever for kitchen cabinets and cupboard space. This condition was overlooked by Miss Stewart in her original recommendation; otherwise I do not think she would have suggested any change.

Instructions have been issued from this office for the construction crew to proceed with the plans as originally drawn. If the Superintendent of Education, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, still considers the alteration desirable, it is not too late for our carpenters to revise the construction. However, in my opinion the addition should be constructed in accordance with the plan as originally drawn.

No arrangements have been made for the electrical installation in the school, and it was not my intention to send an electrician in this year as there was no electrical plant in the district and no building requiring electrical services. If necessary, I can obtain prices for the electrical installation and have this work done this year, but I point out that the time for northern shipments is rapidly drawing to a close and that this order must be placed immediately if materials are to be delivered this year. Please advise by wire your wishes on this matter so that I can make the necessary arrangements.

Your mention of a small building for a lighting plant is the first indication that this office has had that such a

(OVER)
structure would be required. There are no materials on the site as yet, but, if necessary, materials can be obtained from the two-classroom school which is being transferred from Arctic Red River. Please advise if this building is of a temporary nature or is it to be finished off for permanent use.

J. E. Kellett,
A/DISTRICT ENGINEER.
OTTAWA, July 31st, 1950.

Mr. B.E. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa.

Re: File 903-5

This will acknowledge your letter of July 20th in regard to Indian Day School at Fort McPherson, N.W.T. I comment on your letter as follows:

1 - Site

The instructions regarding the choice of site by your school inspector, Mr. J.W. McKinnon, have been forwarded to Mr. J.E. Kellett, Acting District Engineer, Edmonton, together with two photostat copies of the plan which you have sent. Mr. Kellett has been instructed to issue instructions to his representative at Fort McPherson regarding the site of the schoolhouse and site selected for the new schoolhouse when built, and to send a plan if this would reach there in time to be of use.

The plan you submitted and two photostat copies of same are returned for your files, or for such use as you may wish to make of same.

2 - Teacherage

Attached herewith is copy of letter dated July 26th received from Mr. J.E. Kellett. This letter points out in paragraphs 2 and 3 that the changes suggested by Miss Stewart, schoolteacher, should not be followed, as the suggested change would leave no wall space for kitchen cupboards and cupboard space, both of which are very important. It may be true that a rug available for some of the rooms may not now fit in the new school addition, but it would appear more important to provide the kitchen cabinets and cupboard space.

3 - LIGHTING

In the attached letter, paragraph 4, Mr. Kellett reports that no arrangements have been made for the electric wiring in the school addition this year. The wiring involved would be a very small job and the cost would be relatively high to have an electrician call at Fort McPherson for this work. Arrangements could be made next year for wiring in the present school addition to be carried out, when the new two-classroom day school is under construction.

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of August 2 which with attached letter from Mr. R.A. Gibson concerning the progress of work at Fort McPherson.

The work at this settlement was delayed in its commencement till funds were available for this work with the carpenter crew reporting to Fort McPherson on the plane of July 14th, and since that date a crew of four carpenters have been employed on the addition to the Anglican Mission schoolhouse. The foreman has advised this office by radiogram of the material shortages, and orders have been placed for replacement of all materials used in the construction of public privies by the August boats which will arrive in Fort McPherson in late August. It is expected that the R.C.M.P. prefabricated building will arrive by the same shipment.

Delivery of these materials will relieve the situation in respect to the material shortage on the warden's cabin, and will permit the erection of this building. It is very unlikely, however, that this building will be completed this year.

On arrival of materials at Fort McPherson the construction crew will be increased, and every effort made to erect the buildings to a point where they will serve as warehouses for housing building materials for the coming winter.

With reference to your letter of July 28th, the last paragraph regarding the wiring installation for the Mission school, I have arranged with Hillas Electric Co. for the supply of materials and these were made up and shipped before receipt of your letter which arrived on August 1st. The work included in the tender provides for lighting fixtures in the classroom and service rooms of the school, as well as the 12 ft. extension now under construction. The tender is considered fair and reasonable, and is recommended for acceptance.

No funds have been set up for this work and I ask that funds in the amount of $1,181.00 be set up to cover this installation. The placing of this order is extremely irregular, and was taken by this office in view of the very short time remaining in which to place orders for materials delivered this year, as your letter of July 24th implied that electric wiring and housing for the electric power plant were required this year. The electrician is carrying out work at Arctic Red River and Aklavik, and under the circumstances it seemed advisable to provide conveniences for the school if at all possible.

The placing of this order with the electrician was made after despatch of my letter of July 26th and before receiving your letter of July 26th, as the work involved is not very great and fitted in with the electricians movements in this area, and no good reason other than the lack of funds existed for not providing this service.

For your information, we are attaching hereto copies of extracts from a report by Mr. I.M. Marshall of the Engineering and Construction Service of the Department of Resources and Development covering inspections which he made during last summer at Fort McPherson, Arctic Red River, and Fort Good Hope.

R. A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

Encls.
Extract from Mr. I.M. Marshall's Report on inspections made at Fort McPherson, Flirt Good Hope and Arctic Red River.

I inspected the school in company with Mr. Cody the new school teacher. The school had just been finished, and the D.P.W. men had just left 2 days before my arrival. The school was not in good condition being dirty. Apart from this I have the following comments to make:

(a) There were many places where the painting and varnishing had been incompleted or improperly done.

(b) Much paint and putty had been smeared on the windows and window sashes.

(c) The glass door in the china cabinet had been broken. This is an ornamental glass and cannot be duplicated at Fort Good Hope.

(d) Paint had been spilled on the varnished baseboards and floors.

(e) Paint pots and brushes had been left scattered throughout the building.

(f) The diesel and generator had a marked vibration and that vibration was quite perceptible in the teacher's living quarters above.

(g) I counted 13 light bulbs either missing or broken. These of course cannot be replaced in Fort Good Hope.

(h) The wall plug was on the wrong side of the kitchen, it should be on the chimney side.

The vibration in the power unit could be due to the crank shaft being ill fitting or having a slight bend. It may not be important as a power line is being strung from the R.C.C.S. Station, but there will be complaints if they have to use this plant. I question the advisability of placing the concrete floor of the furnace room in either this or any other school. The power plant should be in a separate building with no connecting concrete slab or walk.

The under-structure of the school was examined very
carefully - this is another of the type where the insulation is half in place by shiplap - and no masonite or plywood used. With the shiplap it is difficult to make it tight particularly around the bridging.

I would recommend that all pipes and plumbing be carefully covered with as much moss as can be tucked in. At this school the pipes were quite bare even though there was no water on.

All doors and windows in this school were found firm and well fitting. The Warden's cabin was inspected. This has a full basement which stood up well last winter. The Warden seemed quite satisfied with his house and with the full basement. There was only one door that did not fit properly. The Warden's ice-house has been moved, but has not been levelled, and no fill put in. The roof needs completing, and the D.F.W. left an order for 3 rolls of roofing with the Hudson Bay Company. The door of this ice-house is not really suitable. It is only made of 1 inch material and should be of the refrigerator type.
Extract from Mr. I.M. Marshall's Report, covering inspections made at Fort McPherson, Fort Good Hope, and Arctic Red River.

11. Fort McPherson.

I inspected the school. This is a one-room school purchased some years ago from the Anglican Mission. The present school teacher, Miss Stewart, has been there a year. This school is a definite fire hazard, and having only one door, is dangerous. The door is in the centre of the building and opens directly into a hallway containing an oil heater immediately in front of and close to the door. Oil has been spilt on the floor. There is another heater directly behind this heater in the classroom making really a double hazard. If a fire occurred from either of these 2 heaters, I do not see how between 30 and 40 children would ever get out. A doorway should be cut in the south east corner of the classroom. I would recommend that this door be cut before school opens, and a porch with a second door added.

14. Arctic Red River

Only one building was under construction at Arctic Red River, this is a one-room school. It is started directly on permafrost, and when I was there only the footings had been poured. The site is on a hill with about a 7% grade. The foreman in charge of the P.W.D., Mr. Dean Hawkins, told me it took him 3 weeks to thaw and drain this for the footings. The deepest point was about 7 feet below the original grade. It will be interesting to note the effect of permafrost on this building. The soil here had in spots a full 2 feet of moss and peaty material directly above the permafrost which contained a great deal of ice. I discussed with Mr. Hawkins the various measures he would take to have the ground come back to its original frost condition. I believe he had a very good knowledge of permafrost conditions and will follow the best practice.

The quarters of the R.C.M.P. are the only other...
government buildings. These consist of a single men's quarters and the usual storage houses. The house was one of the few seen that has been banked by a low housing of shiplap and roofing paper enclosing moss well packed for over two feet of height and nearly two feet in width. The resident member of the R.C.M.P. was away on patrol, and I could not obtain his comments on the effectiveness of this type of banking.

In reply to your letter of October 5th concerning the lighting plant provided for the Fort McPherson school, I advise that this is a Kohler fully automatic 5 kw., 110 v. single phase unit, which has been housed in an 8 x 10 shelter, fully insulated and connected to the building. To date no invoice has been received on this unit, nor any correspondence to indicate who placed the order, nor the supply house, although it is known that the lighting plant came from Calgary. No provision has been made to include the cost of this plant as an item of cost against the funds allotted for this year.

It is believed the Kohler Lighting Plant is gasoline operated and I am not familiar with what stocks of fuel have been provided for this unit. I presume, however, that this item of operation has been considered and provided for by the same party who ordered the light plant.

No specific item is being entered in the estimates for the purchase of a lighting plant for the Two-Classroom School that will be erected next year, as it was considered that the 5 kw. unit now in use would be adequate to handle both the Two-Classroom School and the Mission school if necessary, and that no additional power should be provided until a heavier power load has developed in this area. The $10,000 for material purchases during the present fiscal year was to cover building materials only, which will be required to replace materials used on other construction in Arctic Red River and Fort McPherson.

In connection with the attached bill I would like to explain the circumstances which incurred this trip.

On Sept. 8th, 1930 I received a wire stating that the lighting plant and other materials had arrived at McPherson. As your letter of August 18th stated that the Dept. of Public Works were to erect the building I presumed that all arrangements had been made and therefore I proceeded to McPherson on Sept. 6th. However on my arrival I found that the building had not been started and D.P.W. not authorized to go ahead with this building. Nevertheless Major White was at the site and through him, after several wires authority was received to go ahead with the job. In the meantime I finished the wiring of the school and had this work completed on Sept. 10th, in order for the school to open on Monday, Sept. 11th. At this date there had been no start on the above mentioned building, and instead of waiting for the building to be started and completed, I returned to Aklavik.

On Sept. 19th I received a wire that the building was far enough advanced for the plant to be installed. I then, with a helper, proceeded to Fort McPherson on Sept. 20th. On the 24th the job was completed. Even at this late date the building was still not completed. You can readily understand from the above why the job was not finished on my first trip, and why I did not wait for the building to be completed. Trusting this will meet with your approval.

Yours truly,

Department of Indian Affairs

PROPOSED RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
FT. NORMAN

CORRESPONDENCE
Fort Norman, N.W.T., May 1936.

Mr. J. Lorne Turner, Director,
Department of the Interior, Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

On account of the increase of the population, of the needs of a better performance in the training of the children, and of other reasons hereafter mentioned, the people of Norman and Franklin in the N.W.T., WHITES, HALF-BREEDS AND INDIANS, consider the establishment of a boarding school at Norman as corresponding to their needs and desires. In accordance with the terms of Treaty No. 11 whereby: "His Majesty agrees to pay the salaries to instruct the children of said Indians...; in accordance also with the N.W.T. Act, whereby: "The ratepayers of any portion... of the Territories may establish schools therein as they think it fit... (ch: 142: part I A. 12... the citizens of Norman, whose signatures appear hereunder, respectfully request, through your Department, that required provisions be taken to secure the establishment of a boarding school here, in such manner the Department deem it advisable, during the coming year.

The request submitted to your benevolent consideration, postulates in its favour the following reasons.....

1. The GEOGRAPHICAL POSITION of Norman:
   (a) according to its midway location between Providence and Aklavik
   (b) " to its natural centre for the gathering of the Hare Indians tribe in the same school.
   (c) " to its increasing importance of the town.

2. The POPULATION, of Norman and Bear-Lake is, at present, of 395 Indians including 112 children; of 34 Halfbreed children, of 14 White children, Good-Hope has a population of 371 Hare Indians, of 35 Half-breed and White. The number of children averages to 60. Thence, Norman and Good-Hope with their 140 children at the age of attending school, may secure the recruitment of a Boarding school here.

3. Other PSYCHOLOGICAL Factors require also the said school to promote Education, dispel prejudices against it and secure a more efficient influence on the social life of the Natives.
   (a) An hostile mentality in the Indians' minds restrains the attendance at the distant school.
   (b) Antipathetic and indifferent mentalities favoured by the distant school deprive also the children from a suitable training.
4. The HEALTH OF THE NATIVES shall be favoured with a school.

5. The modern EDUCATION, considering as a general principle the necessity of teaching the child in his mother-language and with IT "To neglect the native language is liable to the danger of hindering and ruining the productive activity of the scholars". (African International Institute Postula)...shall find its realization here, by gathering all the Hare Indians in the same one school.

For the above mentioned reasons, WE CITIZENS of Norman, request that the matter be given all worthily consideration.

We subscribe, devotedly yours,

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to submit in the following report, a summary of my recommendations and observations in connection with the North West Territories; I am also dealing herein with the matters I was asked to investigate for J. Lorne Turner, Esq., Director, the request having been sent to you through R. A. Gibson, Esq., Deputy Commissioner:

- 3 - SCHOOL AT FORT NORMAN:

In my opinion there is no question about a school being required at this point: There are 26 children at the Fort, termed as Whites, although some of them are Half-breeds. These children range in age from 5 to 14 years, averaging about 9 years of age. Taking the Indian children in the vicinity of Norman and Bear Lake, there are 66 between the ages of 7 and 16. The total number of children of school age is about 92: I believe the Director has this information. There are so many things to consider in the way of expenses up in that North country, that I believe we should probably endeavour to get a hospital at Norman before even considering the building of a school. However, as I have pointed out, the need is there, especially for the children belonging to White residents of the Fort.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson

Dear Dr. McGill,

On the 29th ultimo the Rev. Dr. Gould, General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, discussed with officers of our Lands, Northwest Territories and Yukon Branch, the matter of the establishment of a residential school or hospital, or both, at Norman.

Dr. Gould stated definitely that a recommendation would be submitted to the Executive Committee of the Missionary Society that a residential school be established at Norman in preference to a hospital. He thought provision should be made for thirty boarders the first year. The accommodation would provide for Indians and half-breeds from the Great Bear Lake and Gravel River areas, also for the day pupils of the Settlement.

Dr. Gould pointed out that the majority of the parents with children of school age in the Norman area were Protestants. However, he wanted it understood that there would be no objection to boarders or day pupils receiving religious instructions outside the school if their parents so desire.

In a message dated the 8th ultimo from the District Agent at Fort Smith he stated that Bishop Breynat was not considering the erection of a residential school at Norman.

In connection with the establishment of a hospital at Norman, Dr. Gould said he thought a separate

Ottawa, 16th November, 1946.

Bernard Neary, Esq.,
Supervisor of Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

I am submitting herewith for your information a copy of the estimated expenditures for education in the Northwest Territories for the fiscal year 1947-48 over and above the amount budgeted for the current year.

You will note that provision has been made for the opening of day-schools at five points, including Fort Rae and Fort Norman. However, these are only temporary expedients, as the need for new residential schools at the two points mentioned is particularly pressing.

Consequently, I would respectfully suggest that in the preparation of the educational estimates for your Branch consideration be given to the inclusion of amounts adequate to cover the cost of construction of new residential schools at Fort Rae and Fort Norman, each capable of accommodating one hundred children. These points are already served with hospital facilities, and the residents are predominately Indian. Fort Rae and district have 636 Dog Rib Indians who are nomadic and visit the Fort only at intervals.

The Fort Norman district contains some 350 treaty Indians, and a copy of a petition for the construction of a residential school is attached. In conversation Bishop Trocellier stated that as both the Rae and Norman areas are predominantly Catholic, he would be prepared to staff the projected schools.
While the main estimates that I have prepared should receive priority, the two suggested residential schools mentioned above merit inclusion, if at all possible.

Re Day-school at Fort Norman

I am attaching hereto copy of a petition for the establishment of a day-school signed by residents of Fort Norman, Northwest Territories, and received by me at this office. With respect to this matter, I should like to comment as follows:

On August 11th I made an investigation of educational facilities at Fort Norman, talked with Constable Hurley of the R.C.M.P., local residents and members of the Roman Catholic mission, and inspected conditions among the natives residing there. The area contains some 350 treaty Indians, together with some whites and half-breeds. I was impressed with the general enthusiasm for a school, and in view of my personal count of more than 70 children of school age I feel that this locality is deserving of immediate attention.

Until such time as a further investigation is possible, I would suggest the following measures:

(1) That for the year ending June 1947 the igloo owned by the Department of National Health and Welfare be made use of as temporary school premises.

(2) That the local residents be responsible for the provision of heat and light.

(3) That the Bureau of Northwest Territories and the Indian Affairs Branch bear the cost of teaching services and school supplies on a pro rata basis.
More detailed information concerning the situation at Fort Rae will be incorporated in the report of the survey trip being prepared by the writer.

FORT NORMAN - PROPOSED INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

At a recent meeting of officials of the Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs and the Indian Affairs Branch, the problem of providing temporary educational facilities at Fort Norman was discussed.

McKinnon when natives of this district were interviewed regarding a school being started at this point, many enquiries have been made at this office by residents as to what action has been taken by the Gov't in this regard. The only information that the writer was able to give to such enquiries was that Mr. W. J. McKinnon was of the opinion that a school was badly needed at this point and that every effort would be made to have a school at Ft. Norman.

3. Recently during a visit by the Indian Agent, Dr. J. P. Harvey of Aklavik, it was learned that the Dept. have had difficulty in obtaining teachers for the schools in Northern points. In this regard I wish to report that the writer was interviewed on 28-3-47 by Mrs. R. H. Botten, wife of the W.O.I., 1/c R.C.S. Fort Norman.

4. Mrs. Botten was formerly a school teacher, having taught in the Provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta. At the present time Mrs. Botten is teaching the White children of this settlement at her home here at Norman. At the time the writer was in conversation with Mrs. Botten, she stated that she had heard that the Gov't. was planning on starting a school at this point and that further she had been given to understand the main reason for a school having not already been started was due to the lack of a teacher. As Mrs. Botten is already teaching a class of six white pupils she is of the opinion that if the Department would make arrangements to secure a building and equipment for a school at Norman that Half-breed and Indian children could be included in her classes. In this regard Mrs. Botten was given the address of Mr. W. J. McKinnon, Supt. of Education, she stating that she would contact him personally.
5. In regard to a building being secured at Ft. Norman for a temporary school, I would refer to a suggestion made by Mr. M. Meikle of the Department during his visit with Mr. McKinnon to this settlement in 1946, that a quonset hut (Igloo) which it is believed is the property of the Dept. of Health and Welfare, be temporarily utilized for a school building. Very little work would be required in this regard, the problem of seating and desks being the largest item.

6. This report has been submitted for the information of the Department concerned for whatever action they should deem advisable. It is respectfully requested, that due to the many enquiries being made at this office by the Natives regarding school, that we please be advised of any decision that is being made. This request is being made so as to allow the Indians concerned to make arrangements for their children should a school be started in Ft. Norman this coming summer.

Dear Sir,

I have recently become resident in Fort Norman, my husband having been posted to the Radio Station here. As we have one child of nine years of age, I accordingly view the problem of schooling, not only for her but for the children of the community at large, as one of prime importance.

I am led to believe that your department has signified willingness to establish a school here and that the chief obstacle has been unsuccessful efforts to procure a teacher. Contingent upon my acceptability I would be more than willing to accept the teaching position, if permitted to do so. I have not practised the profession since my marriage ten years ago but I have, from time to time, rendered assistance and kept in touch. I held a First Class Interim Certificate from Saskatoon Normal School issued in 1924. I taught Ohio School in the district of Imperial, Sask., until the summer of 1935, when I went North to Fort Chipewyan, Alta., and taught a private school there for a year. For a period of four months in 1936 prior to my marriage I taught the school at Camsell Portage, Sask. From these last two appointments it will be seen that I am not unfamiliar with teaching and general conditions in the North.

My marriage of course eliminated the necessity of applying for a permanent certificate, as I had no intention of continuing in the profession as such. However, in the light of the existing situation here and the fact that I feel myself capable of filling this important need, I would be glad to resume teaching and would appreciate my acceptance in this capacity.

I am, by request of respective parents, currently conducting school in my own home for six of the local children. Unfortunately, this is but a portion of the children of school age, as extremely limited accommodation and facilities will permit no more.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are twenty Indian children in the Fort Norman district, in the Northwest Territories, for whom educational facilities are required;

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch has agreed with the Bureau of Northwest Territories and Yukon Affairs to conduct a school at Fort Norman, for the education of Indian, half-breed and white children;

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Meikle

Re: Fort Norman

I carried out an educational survey at Fort Norman on June 13th and 14th, during which time I discussed educational problems with representatives of the R.C.M.P., R.C.G.S., the Hudson's Bay Company, and all the local residents.

I was invited to take part in a meeting attended by all the Indians of this area. During the course of this meeting they requested that the government provide them with a government-operated day school and promised that they would do their very best to see that the children attended school regularly. The local inhabitants informed me that there were 70 children of school age in the vicinity, and that about 40 of them would attend school the first year. Mrs. R. S. Botten, who holds a First Class Teacher's Certificate from Saskatchewan, dated 1934, and who has two and one-half years teaching experience, was the unanimous choice of all the residents as teacher of the proposed school. She has a very fine personality, and I witnessed the excellent training which she has given to a small group of children who are receiving instruction from her in one of the rooms at her home.

My own personal opinion is that we would have about 15 permanent pupils attending school at this settlement during the first year. The enrolment may reach 40 at various seasons, and doubtless there will be an increase in attendance as the natives realize the need for practical educational training.

In any event classroom supplies were ordered on June 14th and it is hoped that a permanent school will be opened at this point as soon as possible in order that we may retain the confidence of the local citizens.

I examined the igloo which had been proposed as temporary quarters for a day school and found it to be most unsuitable. Such a building would be greatly damaged during the process of being moved. It has few windows, poor air space, and would be unhealthy for occupation by children. Therefore, I propose that the government either open a school in the garage owned by the Department of National Health and Welfare, procure a Dallas hut from Norman Wells, or purchase a suitable prefabricated building. I am inclined to the opinion that the latter course would prove to be the most satisfactory.

Mr. Stensby of the Department of Public Works, who was erecting a R.C.M.P. building, said that he would remodel and insulate the garage owned by National Health and Welfare for about $1,000. Failing this he would be free to renovate a Dallas hut for classroom purposes. Mr. Foster of Imperial Oil Exploration at Norman Wells promised Constable L. C. Hunter of Fort Norman that he would provide a Dallas hut at a maximum cost of $900. As the Northern Transportation Company boats are going from the Wells to Norman frequently, there would be no difficulty in having...
one of these buildings transported there. The Dallas huts are 48' x 20' and it would be necessary to dismantle and erect them with care. They are constructed in sections and Mr. McNiven, a member of the Northwest Territories Council, has advised that it would be necessary to place them on a false studding 2' high, re-cut the windows and thus renovate them into permanent buildings. He is of the opinion that they are no use whatsoever unless this renovation is done, and states that by it they can be converted into comfortable and well-appearing permanent buildings.

I looked over the townsite, and all the local residents agreed that we reserve for school purposes 3 acres of land on Lot No. 17, south of the road and adjoining the west boundary of Lot No. 17. This area should be 6 chains running east and west, and 5 chains running north and south. On June 14th I wired Mr. R. A. Gibson, Deputy Commissioner, requesting reservation of the above site. There should be no difficulty in obtaining this area as it already belongs to the Indian Affairs Branch and since the garage owned by National Health and Welfare is at present located thereon.

Should a new school be planned for erection at this point, a bulldozer should be used to remove the moss from the area in order that the permanent frost would disappear and so that the building could be erected on a firm foundation. Local residents informed me that a bulldozer would be on hand at Norman within the next few weeks, and that we should take advantage of this opportunity to have the work done. This work should be begun after the end of this month so that the ground will dry out in August.

The most important factor for the welfare and education of the residents at Fort Norman is a good Indian Agent. The Indian Affairs Branch ought to endeavour to obtain an outstanding married man with practical ability in carpentry, gardening, and practical activities, combined with an understanding of Indians, who would act as Indian Agent while his wife served as teacher. With such a combination the financial remuneration could be made so attractive that the Department would have no difficulty in providing this settlement with the best type of government employees.

J. W. McKinnon.

I am forwarding this note, the monthly Attendance Report of the Fort Norman Day School, for the month of January 1948.

It will be noted that several more Indian children have been enrolled in this school during this month. The attendance so far has been very irregular due to the fact that the parents of the children necessarily have to go many miles from the Settlement in order to make a living. It will also be noted that several children are enrolled in the school and are unable to attend for medical reasons.

As this is the first year a school has been in operation in this district, I have not recommended the suspension of any Family Allowance for non-attendance. The reason for not recommending any suspension of Family Allowance is that the parents appear to be making an effort to have the children attend but owing to financial conditions they are forced to leave the Settlement to make a living.

It is believed that in the coming year a better attendance may be expected, as the natives will be aware of the fact that some measures must be taken, such as having ample fuel supply etc., in order that their children may attend school. It is hoped that the Family Allowance Branch and the Welfare and Training Branch will agree with the procedure adopted and allow me to have another year with the use of persuasion in obtaining a regular school attendance. Should any of the Natives refuse to co-operate, I will not hesitate recommending the Suspension of Family Allowance.

I wish to state that I have recently returned from a visit of every settlement in this Indian Agency, at which time I visited all schools, spending as much time as possible with the teachers.

The other day school of this agency is the Fort Norman Day School, in the charge of Mrs. H. H. Botten, teacher. This school was started in September of 1947, and has been conducted in a temporary building. To date this school has been very much of a success as far as the white and Half Breed children are concerned and also the few Indian children who are able to attend. There are many Indians in this district who should be attending school. It is realized the Indian Act provides all children must attend school where a school is available, however to enforce this for the current year would necessitate most of the families remaining in the settlement and being maintained, at great expense, by the Indian Affairs branch. I do expect to have the Indian pupil attendance increased for the next school term, as financial circumstances, combined with lack of foresight on the part of the Indian have driven them out to their hunting grounds in order to eke out a living. Even the anticipated increase in attendance next term will be small in comparison with the number of school age children.

Dear Mrs. Foss:

On June 3rd Mr. Neary, Superintendent of Education for the Indian Affairs Branch, informed you that he was referring to me one of your previous letters in order that I might answer some of your questions concerning the new school at Fort Norman. I should like to apologize for the fact that Mr. Neary's letter was overlooked, and this accounts for my delay in getting the information to you.

The new school now being constructed at Fort Norman contains two classrooms on the ground floor, together with cloakroom and toilets for boys and girls, plus a storage room. On the second floor are the residential quarters for the teacher, consisting of three bedrooms, a kitchen, a living room, a dining room and a bathroom. Present plans call for the employment of one teacher, but it is expected that the school enrolment by another year will justify the employment of a second teacher. Three bedrooms have been provided in the teacher's quarters in order that the second teacher might be accommodated there. The living quarters are furnished, with the exception of linens and bedding.

The only transportation to Fort Norman is by air. We are at present awaiting a decision as to whether or not the Government will pay air transportation costs for teachers from Edmonton to their destination.

I am sorry that I am not in a position to advise you as to whether or not your husband could obtain employment at Fort Norman.

Mrs. Mary M. Foss,
Furness,
Saskatchewan.
The schools in the Territories follow the Alberta public school curriculum. The enrolment in the Fort Norman school will probably be approximately twenty pupils as a beginning.

Extract from report from Mr. Johnston, District Engineer dated October 18th on the Fort Norman Day School.

RE FORT NORMAN.

A carpenter crew is engaged at Fort Norman and is being retained there over freeze-up. The building is closed in with siding in place and a tar and gravel roof has been proceeded with so as to protect the building, but not wholly completed, cold weather in the late fall preventing its completion. Electrical work has been completed, hot-air heating installed and in operation. The carpenter crew will finish, it is expected, during January. At that time the class could be transferred if desired, from the present temporary quarters, to the new school building. The alternative would be to retain the school in its present quarters until the spring or early summer, when the weather would not be too severe for the transfer. Re; Fort Norman, Indian Day School.

I am attaching herewith the monthly day school reports for the months October to December 1948, inclusive. I regret to report that during this period the attendance of Indian children was practically nil. As you are aware we were without a teacher for the month of September, this being the month when the natives leave the settlements for the bush to obtain fish for the winter. As it so happened that the school was not opened in September, all the Indians and their families moved out to the bush and shortly after the "freeze-up period" set in. It therefore made it impossible for any of the children to return to Fort Norman until the month of December.

I am happy to report that since the Christmas holiday season that the attendance of the Ft. Norman School is approximately twenty one pupils, half of this number being Indian children. It may be mentioned that to obtain this attendance of Indian children, it has been necessary for me to place the majority of the families with children on welfare relief. It is becoming extremely difficult to have these families remain in the settlements and be self reliant as the fur and fur prices are on a steady decline while the prices of food are steadily climbing. The attendance as stated above, or slightly higher, will be maintained until the end of March, 1949, at which time I will be obliged to allow the Indians to return to the bush for what is known as a "Spring Hunt".

The largest attendance of Indian children in the Fort Norman School, could be obtained
during the months of July and August. I would therefore request your permission to have the Fort Norman Day School remain open for those months for the attendance of Indian children only.

Recently while in Edmonton, Alta., on other duties, I was in conversation with Mr. Johnston, District Engineer of the Department of Public Works. Mr. Johnston assured me that the new school building at Fort Norman, would be ready for opening by the first of July 1949. I would therefore suggest, should you agree that the school be opened for the months of July and August, that the teacher for the school year 1949/50, be at Fort Norman during the later part of June 1949.

L.C. Hunter,
Superintendent,

Dear Mr. Neary;

Due to heavy ice conditions here during break-up your letter dated April 14 just arrived.

As briefly as possible I will attempt to sum up the school situation here in Fort Norman.

There are 31 children of school age among the natives...25 Catholic, 6 Protestant. At Franklin there are 33...all Catholic. Whites number about 8 Prot. (4 of whom are leaving soon) and 4 Cath.

From these figures it is easy to see that the children are in the vast majority Catholic and although we have no Catholic school for them here as yet, still we wish them to learn something about God in school.

For this reason we are anxious that a Catholic teacher be appointed to this post. Unfortunately the present teacher, although excellent, is Catholic in name only.

We understand that the school now being completed here at a cost of around $60,000.00 is being put up for the Indians and therefore it seems logical that they should be served in preference to the few whites who may attend. But these Natives are anxious that the burden of instructing their offspring in the knowledge of God and His laws be taken from their shoulders and put upon those of the better qualified school teacher. During the winter I filled in, in this capacity, for the one half hour of school time per week that was allotted me. We need more time. And this time should not be at the end of the last day of the week...or at the end of any day of the week for that matter, because it gives the impression that they are staying "after" school, especially when they see the Protestant children troop out. The Knowledge of God and His law is the most important subject a child can possibly study at school.

Although the Canadian Gov. is pouring money into this Fort in the form of a beautiful new school, they seem to be ignorant of the fact that the majority of the Indian children will be unable to benefit by this school because their parents are trappers and cannot afford to stay in the Fort long. As much as they would like to leave their children in school this cannot be done if there is no place for them to eat and sleep. A boarding school is imperative here if the Indians are to benefit by this recent outlay. The Indian agent here agrees that the logical solution is to obtain the services of several of those Sisters who are successfully caring for Indian children at other posts while their parents are in the bush.

Sincerely

Rev. Bernard Brown O.M.I.

I have had inquiries from Reverend Father Brown of the R.C. Mission at Fort Norman with regard to the teaching of religious instruction at the Fort Norman Indian Day School.

It has long been the policy of the Department to permit a priest to carry out one half-hour of religious instruction daily in schools in which R.C.'s are in the majority. The time of this religious instruction is usually set by mutual agreement with the Indian Superintendent, the teacher and the priest concerned.

Naturally, no pupils are permitted to be present at any such religious instruction unless the parents or guardians of such pupils desire it.

I have had enquiries from Reverend Father Brown of the R. C. Mission at Fort Norman with regard to the teaching of religious instruction at the Fort Norman Indian Day School.

It has long been the policy of the Department to permit ministers and priests to carry out one half-hour of religious instruction daily in schools in which their particular denomination is in the majority. The time of this religious instruction is usually set by mutual agreement with the Indian Superintendent, the teacher and the priest concerned.

Naturally, no pupils are permitted to be present at any such religious instruction unless the parents or guardians of such pupils desire it.

In other words, children of another faith usually remain in another classroom of the school during such religious instruction and this time can be spent by them in current events, visual education, handicrafts, vocational training or other subjects of an allied field.

This arrangement has worked quite well at other schools and, I believe, you can discuss the matter with Father Brown and the teacher and arrange for a similar plan at Fort Norman. You might write following this interview.

Bernard Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Welfare Activities
Fort Norman
September - October

Since the beginning of the school term all Indian homes have been visited at least three times in the interest of reviewing living conditions, regular attendance at school, adult education, etc. Numerous visits have been made to several homes known to be infested with vermin. I am happy to report that this situation has been greatly relieved if not entirely overcome among the resident population. Great care is exercised in seeing that school children are washed and have their hair combed before arriving at school. During recess period, twice daily, the children receive vitamin pills, milk or hot cocoa and cookies.

On September 19th, night classes were started in an effort to at least arrive the adult Indian at a point where he can read and write leisurely and do fundamental arithmetic. So far the response has been gratifying. A great deal of difficulty...
is experienced because of their constantly moving from place to place. As a result, their attendance is irregular and this tends to hold a check on their advancement. I find that the older Indians who actually have a desire to learn experience very little difficulty in doing so. It is not uncommon for one of these people to arrive at school unable to speak or understand a word of English and at the end of the first session be able to entirely recite the alphabet, read and understand thoroughly all of the first of a series of grade one readers.

Classes are conducted from 7:00 - 10:00 P.M. Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Those attending vary in age from thirteen to fifty years of age. To date the highest register number is 16. Many natives are beginning to realize that this is an opportunity and during the past two weeks the attendance has raised steadily as is indicated on the attached attendance sheet.

Educational films are being shown to the entire population from time to time. Film strips are shown to the night class students once a week. A great deal of enthusiasm is displayed and this method seems invaluable in getting ideas across to those who have little command of the English tongue.

A program of entertainment is at present being considered so that during the winter months at least the natives will have educational and recreational opportunities.

July 16th, 1915.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I have pleasure in enclosing Returns of the Anglican Day School at Fort Norman for the Quarters ending September 30, and December 31, 1914; also for March 31st, 1915, and June 30, 1915. These four Returns were handed to me yesterday upon my annual visit by our Missionary in charge, Mr. W.S. Tremain. He is new to the work, and I have given him instructions to forward the Returns to you each quarter in future. He has kept school very regularly, and although the average attendance is not large, we have the satisfaction of knowing everything is being done for the education of the children of this place. The teaching is in English, and the children are not only receiving instruction, secular and religious, but are being taught their duty as citizens of the British Empire.

I will ask you to place all grants for our schools to the credit of the Mackenzie River Diocesan Account in the Imperial Bank Athabasca, Alberta, and advise me of the payment at the above address.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours faithfully,

Rt Rev. Jas. R. Lucas.
Bishop of Mackenzie River.

Dear Sir,

I beg to enclose Reports of the Day School at Fort Norman N.W.T. for the Quarters ending September 30 & December 31, 1915, and March 31 & June 30th, 1916 and trust same will prove in order.

The Rev. W.S. Tremain who is the teacher, has included the names of all the Indian Children who have at some time during the past two tears attended the school. Owing to the scarcity of food near the Fort the Indians have been forced to go further afield and consequently the number of children able to attend School has been very small. I pointed out to Mr Tremain that in future he will not include the names on the reports unless they record attendance. It was not possible to correct these forms as we have no others on hand. I will therefore ask you to forward a number of copies of Return forms to Mr. Tremain at your early convenience by registered mail to ensure their being forwarded during the Winter. School has been kept very regularly and although the numbers are not large the Report represents good, steady work on the part of the teacher.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours faithfully,

Jas. A. Lucas,
Bishop of Mackenzie River.

Mr. Hoey

This morning I quoted to you a wireless message which School Inspector McKinnon indicated that he had addressed to you. I am now in receipt of a somewhat similar message which Mr. McKinnon has addressed to me and which reads -

"Suggest you negotiate for the acquisition of minimum of 15 Dallas huts from Imperial Oil Explorations, Norman Wells, for erection of public day school buildings and staff quarters at various locations. Suggestion is made as action to acquire the buildings may be taken at once lest other interested parties may gain possession of these buildings now in the North. If fiscal year 1947-48 appropriation will not purchase them, suggest arrangements be made with Imperial Oil to retain and earmark for school purposes until payment can be approved through the normal government channel of procedure. Above suggestions have been discussed with Major White B.P.W. and many others."

However, our experience in buying these Dallas huts has not been particularly fortunate and we find that the longer the acquisition is delayed the more apt we are to get the less desirable buildings. In other words, everything gets picked over pretty well. We have not money to buy Dallas huts this year. You may be more fortunate. If you are interested we can ask Fred Fraser, our Mining Recorder at Yellowknife, who is making a trip down the Mackenzie in his own boat to have a look at these huts and give you a businessman's view on same.

R.A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

Ottawa, June 30th, 1947.

Memorandum:

MR. JOEY

Fort Norman Indian Day School

I had an opportunity of discussing with Mr. Meikle of N.W.T. Administration, the telegrams received from Mr. McKinnon concerning the above school.

We agreed that it would be inadvisable to buy more than one of these buildings. Mr. Meikle's past experience leads him to the conclusion that they are of a very temporary nature and would not be satisfactory for any length of time.

Therefore, if you so approve, I intend to wire Mr. McKinnon advising him that we will purchase only one of these buildings and that for use at Fort Norman.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
4 July, 1947.

Superintendent of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch Department of Mines and Resources.

I attach hereto, copy of letter from the District Engineer at Edmonton concerning the release of a Dallus Hut for school purposes at Fort Norman, N.W.T. The hut is presently at Great Bear River.

Should you be interested in the acquisition of thus hut, will you kindly so state and also advise if you will assume the cost of transportation from Great Bear River to Fort Norman, and the care and erection of the hut at Fort Norman.

FA/S.

R. Blais
Chief Engineer.
The following radiogram, dated June 23rd, has been received from T.Newcomen, Engineer, at Great Bear River, N.W.Ts —

"REFERENCE DALLAS HUT USED AS COOK AND MESS HUT stop UNLESS OTHER ARRANGEMENTS MADE THIS BUILDING WOULD COME IN USEFUL FOR SCHOOL USE FORT NORMAN stop POLICE ADVISE THAT ALL RE-ERECTING WOULD BE LOCKED AFTER BY LOCAL PEOPLE stop THIS HUT IS NOT SHOWN ON OUR INVENTORY stop SCHOOL ACCOMMODATION AT NORMAN BADLY NEEDED stop PLEASE ADVISE".

I do not know what has led up to this radiogram beyond that it must be information which Mr.Newcomen obtained locally, as I have had no previous intimation that a Dallas Hut was required for school purposes at Fort Norman, before Mr.Newcomen left here. I discussed with him, however, the possibility that some of the buildings now at Great Bear River would be dismantled by his crew and it was believed at that time none of these would be moved to Fort Franklin for the purpose of a school and teachersage. The Dallas Hut referred to by Mr.Newcomen is a used construction Camp remaining from Great Bear River construction programme.

The last word I had regarding any buildings at Fort Franklin was a letter received from you with attached copy of letter of May 10th, from R.A.Honey, Director of Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources. This letter stated that Mr.J.W.MacKinnon, Inspector of Schools for the Northwest Territories, would inspect conditions at Fort Franklin and advise further. I must point out, however, that if it is intended to have any buildings moved to Fort Franklin, I should know about this very shortly.

Furthermore, the question of moving freight this year is very acute, and if it is intended to move these buildings to another location, arrangements should be made shortly with the water transportation company.

There are at Great Bear River, in addition to the construction Camp suggested by Mr.Newcomen as being required at Fort Norman, the following:

One Caboose suggested by Mr.Oldham for Great Bear River, at Franklin end of road;
One Caboose suggested by Mr.Oldham for Great Bear River, at head of Rapids;
2 Igloos, part of which were suggested for Indian School facilities and teachersage at Fort Franklin, but the situation regarding same is now unknown.

I have just received a report from Mr.Newcomen that owing to rainy weather and breakdown in equipment, the work at Great Bear River Road has not proceeded as fast as might have been expected. I have
no up to date information regarding his prospect of finishing the work this year, and it is just possible that several of these buildings might be required at Great Bear River another year, if —

(a) it is necessary to ask for further funds this year which cannot be granted; or

(b) further work is done on the Road next year.

In any case, I would suggest the activities of this Department could be consolidated into the two Cabanas and the two Igloos, so that the construction Camp suggested for Fort Norman might be released at once if this decision is made.

Will you please draw the matter of this construction Camp for Fort Norman, as a school, to the attention of the proper authority, and let me know.

W.J. Johnston,
Acting District Engineer.

P.S. The two Igloos are 16' x 32' each instead of the regulation 16' x 40'.

July 15, 1948.

R. A. Hoey, Esq., Director, Indian Affairs Branch, Booth Building, Ottawa.

Re: School Site - Fort Norman

Our District Agent at Fort Smith, Mr. Fred Fraser, recently visited Fort Norman and confirmed the choice of site for the new school previously made by Inspector of Schools McKinnon and District Engineer Johnston. The site selected is Lot 17, which property is already owned by the Indian Affairs Branch. This lot has a road frontage of about 660 ft. and an average depth of 530 ft., giving a total area of 8 acres.

The District Agent reports that there is a slough at the rear of Lot 17 that can be drained by the excavation of a ditch about one-quarter of a mile long from the easterly end of Lot 17 to the bank of the Mackenzie River, passing through Lot 23 which is vacant Crown land. He estimates that the cost of such drainage would amount to $1400. We are now asking the Department of Public Works to verify this estimate.

The location of the new school has already been staked out on Lot 17. It is therefore suggested that steps be taken to reserve for school purposes this area which is at present owned by your Branch.

R. A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Neary:

I have your letter regarding the building of an Indian Day School at Fort Norman on Lot 17 which this Service purchased from the Anglican Church. I wonder if you could arrange to get a map of the settlement with buildings which are at present on Lot 17 marked in on their proper location. A sketch showing these and showing the low-lying land which should be drained is almost a necessity for us to make a decision.

As you know, we are erecting a Nursing Station there almost immediately and we eventually expect to replace the Fort Norman Hospital.

The Northwest Territories Administration also erected some buildings on this lot and we have nothing to show just what space is available. If there is still room after the Nursing Station is built and a site for the hospital you are certainly welcome to use such space for your Indian Day School.

**RE FORT NORMAN.**

A carpenter crew is engaged at Fort Norman and is being retained there over freeze-up. The building is closed in with siding in place and a tar and gravel roof has been proceeded with so as to protect the building, but not wholly completed, cold weather in the late fall preventing its completion. Electrical work has been completed, hot-air heating installed and in operation. The carpenter crew will finish, it is expected, during January. At that time the class could be transferred if desired, from the present temporary quarters, to the new school building. The alternative would be to retain the school in its present quarters until the spring or early summer, when the weather would not be too severe for the transfer. This, however, is a matter for local decision. Some work will be needed next year, such as outside painting, installation of plumbing and other small items of unfinished work.

Shipping instructions as follows:

To reach Waterways May 15th for forwarding by Northern Transportation Company.
Ottawa, October 25, 1948.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Acting Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

I am attaching copy of a letter of the 20th instant received from the Chief Engineer, Department of Public Works, together with copies of Mr. Johnston's report of the 14th instant and estimate of additional funds required to complete the Fort Norman two-classroom day school.

This is a matter which the Department of Public Works should have referred to you, as these schools are being constructed by money provided by your Branch. Would you please let me know whether these additional funds will be available and when you expect the building will be ready for occupancy.

Encs.

R. A. Gibson,
Director.

P.S. It does seem to me that the cost of this school so greatly exceeds the estimate that we would be warranted in asking for more information.

Director.

20 October, 1948.

Director, Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources.

Enclosed herewith is a copy of letter dated October 14th, in which our District Engineer states that the cost of the 2 classroom day school and teacher's quarters at Fort Norman, N.W.T., is going to be higher than originally provided for.

Attached to the copy of his letter is copy of the present estimated cost of the school, which amounts to $71,000, approximately.

The District Engineer points out that the $40,000 as originally estimated was a tentative figure made before complete plans, specifications and bills of materials were on hand.

In his letter of April 15th last, copy of which was sent to you on April 21st, the District Engineer pointed out that the estimated costs of the schools for various points in the Northwest Territories were tentative and stated, "It must be stressed that there has been insufficient time to make a detailed estimate here as the working plans and bills of material are just now being received. It will only be possible at a later date to give you a more accurate statement of the expenditure to be incurred this year on the school project".

Will you please let me know when additional funds required for this work may be made available to this Department.

(Sgd) R. Blais,

R. Blais,
Chief Engineer.

EVG/S
I am replying to your telegram of October 8th in reference to request that $20,000 be made available immediately for the 2- Classroom Day School and Teacher's Quarters at Fort Norman, N.W.T.

You ask regarding commitments made to H. Kelly and Company for plumbing; Hillas Electric Company for electrical installation; Barry Sheet Metal Company for hot-air heating; also an Order in Council approval to C. L. Cinnamon for lumber.

Attached is a statement showing details of the expenditure to date, and the balance of funds which will be required this fiscal year.

When the school programme was undertaken the project was begun in a hurry before plans and specifications were fully developed and with only partial bills of material. At Fort Norman a tentative figure of $40,000 was given for this work, and this was done without having an opportunity to prepare a detailed estimate. It was not by any means to be considered as an estimate of cost of the structure completed, and this point was stressed at that time.

According to the attached statement the expenditure during the present fiscal year will amount to approximately $71,000. As $40,000 has been provided, there will be required an additional $31,000 in order to complete the project.

The carpenter crew is now remaining at Fort Norman for freeze-up and with the present crew, it is expected work will finish about February 1st, unless more carpenters are provided to speed up the work. The cost, however, of sending in more carpenters would hardly be warranted in view of the air forces involved, unless there were a demand for early occupancy of this building. This hardly seems the case, since school classes are now being carried on in a temporary building in the near vicinity.

Work has been completed under the contracts of Barry Sheet Metal Company for hot-air heating; Hillas Electric Company for electrical installation, and H. Kelly and Company for plumbing. It is not necessary to provide an electric generator (as is the case in some locations) as the current is being provided from the generator (generating plant) of Royal Canadian Corps of Signals. The building will require very little work next season beyond painting the exterior, it not being possible to do such work in the late fall.

May I enquire if the amount of $31,000 will be provided shortly for this project.

(Sgd) W. J. Johnston,

W. J. Johnston,
District Engineer.

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 25, advising that an additional $31,000.00 is required in order to complete the erection of the Fort Norman Indian Day School.

On October 21, I wrote to the Chief Engineer of the Department of Public Works, asking for the estimated funds which would be required to complete not only the Fort Norman School but also the other schools to be erected in the Northwest Territories.

Please find attached a copy of the reply which I have just received from Mr. Blais, the Chief Engineer. You will note that a total of $237,200.00 will be required for these projects.

In view of the large amount involved, I would recommend that a meeting of the Sub-committee on Education of the Northwest Territories Council be called in the near future to discuss this situation.

was done on advice received from your Branch. You will note that in his letter of October 20, Mr. Blais makes the following remarks:

"The District Engineer points out that the $40,000.00 as originally estimated was a tentative figure made before complete plans, specifications and bills of materials were on hand".

In view of the fact that each of these schools is now going to cost nearly twice the amount provided for in our Estimates, it is felt that we must thoroughly review this situation in the near future.

Acting Director.

1. Relative to the above, would advise that at approx. 10:40 p.m. of date, a telephone call was received at this Det., to the effect that the new School building at Norman, which is still under construction and being built by the Dept. Indian Affairs, was on fire. The request was made that if any fire extinguishers were available here to take same along.

2. Immediate patrol was made by writer to scene of the fire. Upon arrival a cursory glance revealed that no flames were evident, but gushes of smoke were issuing from the door and window of the furnace room. Writer, together with members of the D.P.W. under Construction Foreman O.N. Neilson, Mr. H.C. Hunter, Indian Agent and Mr. W.G. MacKinnon, local Postmaster, R.M., entered the furnace room, when it was noted that smoke appeared to be the thickest in and around the base of the oil furnace.

3. After emptying several extinguishers of pyrene into the smoke, it was found that the oil furnace itself was not on fire but the wooden joists supporting the cement floor and also the furnace were burning.

4. In the absence of a basement under the furnace room, it was quite evident that the only way to get at the burning joists was to remove the oil furnace, knock a hole through the cement and thus extinguish the blaze, which, by this time, was getting worse.

5. The latter course was followed and the fire in the joists was extinguished after fighting same for approx. 2½ hours, pouring everything from pyrene, water and snow into the burning sections.

6. After the fire was out an examination was made to try and determine its origin, and after same was carried out it was agreed by all present that (1) there was insufficient gravel between the actual floor of the furnace to the bottom of same; and (2) that the cement floor was not thick enough (3"), with the result that the terrific heat generated by the oil furnace had gone through the gravel base and cement floor, and had finally ignited the wooden joists over a period of time.

7. The foregoing points were taken up with Mr. Neilson, D.P.W. foreman on 19th inst. and who advised that the furnace, cement floor, etc., had been built according to specifications on the blue-print, in view of which, origin of the fire itself was the blame of nobody in the settlement.

Over a month has now transpired since the second duplicate express receipt went forward, but we have not as yet received settlement. The Honorable Clifford Sifton,
Minister of the Interior,

Sir,

For the last eight or ten years we have been tantalized by unfulfilled hopes of obtaining from your Department a Grant-in-Aid for our Schools in this District. Having been so unsuccessful with the Indian Commissioner at Regina I now, honorable sir, appeal to you direct.

We have schools at Hay River, Fort Simpson, Fort Norman, Fort McPherson, and Herschel Island.

The one at Hay River has about twelve boarders besides scholars, and is spoken of very highly by travellers who have passed there lately, including Inspector Routledge of the Mounted Police; and it would soon be much larger and more efficient but for the lack of proper accommodation.

The others are day schools, and, I think, are equally deserving of praise for the results accomplished under such circumstances.

I therefore earnestly appeal to your Honor for a Grant-in-Aid for each of the above on the usual conditions, making allowances for the difficulty, under our peculiar circumstances, of always maintaining the number usually required; and a Grant to put up a suitable building at Hay River, and provide necessary school outfit, such as books, slates, maps, etc.

The inrush of gold-seekers is going to affect the condition of the natives very considerably, and I think your Department ought to render prompt aid in the above matters as one of the best ways of benefiting them.

Commending the above to your favorable consideration,

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Very faithfully yours,

W. D. MacKenzie

OTTAWA, 12th April, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

His Lordship, the Church of England Bishop of Mackenzie River applies on behalf of the boarding school at Hay River for an increase of ten more pupils and that the per capita grant be augmented to $100.00. He also asked for funds to put up a more suitable schoolroom, or to enlarge the present one.

In connection with this application I may say that provision is at present made for 20 pupils at $72.00 per capita. They had an average attendance last year of 33 out of an enrollment of 40, which is 13 pupils more than are paid for.

This school is in Treaty 8 and so far the Department has very little information concerning it, although Mr Inspector Macrae on educational matters in this Treaty in 1900, speaking of this school say that "It is a small but most successful school."

Regarding the application to increase the rate of the grant, I do not see that the Department could entertain it as all the other schools in the Treaty would expect similar treatment.

The request for funds to enlarge the school room space is too indefinite to be dealt with. The Department might decide whether it would provide for more pupils or not.

OTTAWA, 9th June, 1904:

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 20th ultimo relative to the grant paid to the Bay River Boarding School, I beg to say that during the September quarter of 1902, the pupils were shown to have been in attendance only 27 days out of the full quarter of 92 days and payment was made at a proportionate rate. The principal states that their absence was due to measles.

In December quarter 1902 the pupils were shown to have been at the school only 59 days out of 92 days, and for the March quarter 1903 their attendance is given as 61 days out of the total of 90 days. Payment was in each case made in accordance with the return.

The return for June quarter 1903 was only received by the Department on the 28th Jan. 1904 and shows that the highest attendance of any pupil was 64 days out of a total number of 91 days in the quarter and payment was made accordingly.

Although the returns show this school to be carrying pupils in excess of the 20 provided for, still the grant can only be paid for the first 20 pupils enrolled.

No returns have been received from this school since the one for June Qr '03.

Hon David Laird,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.:

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Secretary

Aug. 29, 1904.

Dear Mr. Laird,

I have just returned from visiting the Mackenzie River Missions and find awaiting me yours of 14 June, No. I22/82, enclosing copy of letter from Ottawa relative to mine of May 13th. re shortage of Grant paid to the Hay River Boarding School.

I do not know how to account for the low attendance excepting through the measles, but am writing to enquire.

With regard to the measles I may say that I think it rather hard on us the Department cutting down the Grant on that account.

The children were all at the school and had to be fed and cared for just the same. The salary of the Principal, the Teachers, and other helpers had to be paid as usual. In fact extra expense had to be incurred as nearly everyone was stricken.

As therefore the low attendance was due to no fault or negligence of the school staff, but entirely to sickness, I think that it would be only fair and just that the Department pay the full Grant for that period, and I would respectfully press for such payment.

The maintenance of the school is a great tax upon us, and unless we get the full amount of the Government Grant, which comes far short of the actual expense, I fear that we shall be unable to continue it.

With very kind regards to Your Honor

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

The Hon. David Laird,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.

(signed) W.D. Mackenzie River.
